971101
*041  $atur
*24510$aNewroz
*260  $aTurkey
$c1993
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression 
eXchange)/Committee to Protect Journalists
*505  $aNote: On 30 September 1993 the Istanbul State Security Court 
ruled to suspend the publication of the monthly magazine "Newroz" 
magazine for a month for publishing articles that were deemed as 
separatist propaganda. The editor-in-chief, Dogan Karakuzu, was 
sentenced to six months in prison and a fine of 50 million Turkish lira 
(approx. USD 5,000). This is only one of the many cases pursued against 
the magazine in court. There are 24 cases against "Newroz" currently 
being tried, and eight others have already been concluded. All but two 
issues of the publication have been subject to prosecution. The 
magazine reports that its staff has also been under constant harassment 
by the security forces.
*506  $bCensoring body: Istanbul State Security Court
*518  $aSeptember 30, 1993
*518  $3Magazine
*651  $a8048
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aSuspended
^
971102
*041  $atur
*24510$aOzgur Gundem
*260  $aTurkey
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
Reporters sans frontieres
*505  $aNote: 18 February 1994 the security court of Istanbul sentenced 
Yasar Kaya, owner of the pro-Kurdish daily Ozgur Gundem to four years 
inprisonment and a fine of 572 million pounds (US
$30,000) and Davut Karadag, former editor-in-chief a fine of 431 
million Turkish pounds (22,600 dollars). Ozgur Gundem was banned once 
again from publication for a month. Yasar Kaya and Davut Karadag were 
convicted for having published articles on the Kurdish question which 
appeared in the 27 April 1993 issues of Ozgur Gundem and were judged to 
be "inimical to national security". The judgements were based on 
Article 8 of the Turkish anti-terrorist legislation which represses all 
"separatist propaganda".  At the same time, and for the same reasons, 
the daily Ozgur Gundem was prohibited from publishing for one month. 
This is the the fourth edict of this kind since 19 November 1993 which 
represents four months of closure. The Turkish Supreme Court approved 
14 April 1994 a lower court's closure decision and ordered the 
pro-Kurdish daily "Ozgur Gundem" to cease publication for 15 days. The 
approval was the first among a series of closure decisions given 
against "Ozgur Gundem", all being appealed to the Supreme Court. The 
newspaper's editors expect the rest of the decisions to be approved as 
well in the next few weeks, mounting to an eight-and-a-half-month shut 
down. The editors decided to close the newspaper down permanently. The 
newspaper had started publication in May 1992.
*506  $bCensoring body: Turkish Supreme Court
*518  $a18 February 1994 , 14 April 1994
*518  $3Newspaper
*651  $a8048
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aClosed
*692  $aSuspended
^

*505  $aNote: "Azadi", a weekly magazine, has had nine of its thirteen 
issues seized in the first three months of this year.

971104
*041  $atur
*24510$aOzgur Gundem (New Agenda) ; Yeni Ulke ; Yeni Insan, Politika, 
Eylem, Sanat (New Human, Politics, Activity, Art)
*260  $aTurkey
$c1992
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
The Committee to Protect Journalists
*505  $aNote: At least a dozen issues of the Ozgur Gundem and Yeni Ulke 
have been confiscated, including the following: Ozgur Gundem issues 
dated October 7, 8, 9, 10 and 11 1992. They were seized by order of the 
Istanbul State Security Law under the Anti-Terror Law. Among the 
offending items were reportedly an interview with PKK leader Abdullah 
Ocalan and PKK statements on clashes in Northern Iraq. Ozgur Gundem 
issues dated September 19 and 20. They were reportedly confiscated by 
order of the Istanbul State Security Court on the ground that they 
contained "separatist propaganda." The offending articles were one by a 
soldier in the state of emergency region and another that dealt with 
police torture. Yeni Ulke's August 30 issue. It was confiscated by the 
Istanbul State Security Court under Article 8 of the Anti-Terror Law. 
The order alleged that an interview with Abdullah Ocalan and an article 
by owner Serhat Bucak contained separatist propaganda.Trial began 
against writer Ismael Besikci and 125 others on 17 March 1993 in 
connection with a statement sent to the UN about human rights in 
Turkey. The 126 face charges under Article 8 of the 'Law to Fight 
Terrorism'. 'Yeni Insan, Politika, Eylem, Sanat' (New Human, Politics, 
Activity, Art) was confiscated on 17 April 1993 by Istanbul SSC due to 
article by Besikci entitled 'But Turkey is not independent'.
*506  $bCensoring body: Istanbul State Security Court
*518  $aJuly 10 and November 11, 1992
*518  $aMarch 5 and May 7, 1993
*518  $3Newspapers
*651  $a8048
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aSeized
^
971106
*041  $atur
*24510$aEkonomi Politika
*260  $aTurkey
$c1993
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/
*505  $aNote: In its issue (28 march-4 April) Ekonomi Politika (EP), 
"Economy and Politics", the weekly news magazine owned by the Milliyet 
group published a cover story on the "Uzan case". Witnesses and 
documents claimed "illegal acts committed" by the Uzan group since 1964 
in the cover story which Milliyet directors already knew about. This 
issue was the last one published by a group of 22 journalists who all 
resigned 31st of march to protest the attitude of Mr. Dogan and Mr. 
Uzan. The Milliyet group owner, has first fired 3 journalists 
responsible for the cover story and then ordered the confiscation of 
thousands of copies of the issue on sale. Milliyet's men gave strange 
explanations to the news stands :"There are so many technical faults", 
"There is a juridical problem in one article so we have to act before 
the prosecutor". Mr. Dogan has now his name engraved in the black book 
of Turkish press history as the "first newspaper owner who confiscated 
his own weekly".
*506  $bCensoring body: Owner of the Milliyet Press group and owner of 
the Uzan banking and media holding
*518  $aApril 1993
*518  $3Magazine
*651  $a8048
*691  $aOther
*692  $aSeized
^
971107
*041  $atur
*10010$aArsel, Ilhan
*24510$aSeriat ve Kadin (Women and the Sharia) ; Aydin ve Aydin 
(Intellectuals and Intellectuals)
*260  $aTurkey
$c1987
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
International PEN Writers in Prison Committee
*505  $aNote: Ilhan Arsel, Turkish writer and law professor. Now living 
in USA. Fatwa, delcaring him an apostate, reported to have been given 
against him by Cemalettin Kaplan, a Muslim cleric living in Germany, 
following the 1987 publication of his book 'Seriat ve Kadin' (Women and 
the Sharia). Reported to have been demonstrations, led by Kaplan, in 
Germany calling for Arsel's death. Istanbul Public Prosecutor also 
reported to have brought case against Arsel for the book and for his 
book, 'Aydin ve Aydin' (Intellectuals and Intellectuals), published in 
December 1992. Case against 'Aydin ve Aydin' is under Article 175 of 
the Penal Code, prohibiting publication of blasphemous material. Book 
banned in February 1993 after it was given to Religious Affairs 
Department for them to review. State decided around 9 June 1993 to 
prosecute Arsel for 'Aydin ve Aydin' under Article 175 of the Turkish 
Penal Code for insulting holy books, Islam and the prophet Mohammed. 
Kaplan has said he may deliver another fatwa on Arsel in connection 
with the new book.
*506  $bCensoring body: Religious Affairs Department
*518  $a1987, 1992
*518  $3Book
*651  $a8048
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aCensored
^
971108
*041  $atur
*24510$aOzgur ulke
*260  $aTurkey
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
Reporters sans frontieres
*505  $aNote: "Ozgur Ulke" was created on 28 April 1994 and has already 
been the object of legal action. Its first issue was also seized by 
Turkish authorities. "Ozgur Ulke" was created by the publishers of the 
now-defunct newspaper "Ozgur Gundem". The latter newspaper definitively 
ceased publication on 15 April 1994 after a court-ordered 15-day 
suspension of its publication. At a press conference on that day 
Zubeyir Aydar, owner of "Ozgur Gundem", pointed out that many other 
actions against the newspaper were pending and that if they were 
awarded the newspaper would be ordered closed for a total of eight and 
a half months. He also listed the effects of the repressive measures 
"Ozgur Gundem" had been subjected to since its creation in May 1992: 35 
of its employees are in prison, the number of court cases against it 
totals 363, the possible amount of fines to be levelled against it is 
14 million Turkish lira, and the possible length of prison terms handed 
down to its staff and representatives could total 35 years.
*506  $bCensoring body: Turkish authorities
*518  $aApril 15, 1994
*518  $3Newspaper
*651  $a8048
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aSeized
^
971109
*041  $atur
*24510$aYeni Ulke
*260  $aTurkey
$c1992
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
CPJ's Attacks on the Press 1992
*505  $aNote: The Istanbul State Security Court ordered the 
confiscation of the April 4 issue of the weekly Yeni Ulke on the basis 
of Article 6 of the Anti-Terror Law. The offending items were an 
interview with a commander of the Kurdish Workers' Party, or PKK, and 
an article on a report about the PKK that had been made to the United 
Nations.

971118
*041  $aara
$afre
*24510$aAl-Mounqidh ; Al-Forqane
*260  $aAlgeria
$c1992
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
CPJ's Attacks on the Press 1992
*505  $aNote: The administrative chamber of the Algiers Court ordered 
the Islamic Salvation Front (FIS) dissolved, thereby permanently 
closing the party's organs: the Arabic-language weekly Al- Mounqidh and 
the French language weekly Al-Forqane. The court's ruling, in response 
to a petition by the minister of interior, was based on the party's 
violation of Article 5 of the Law on Political Parties, which prohibits 
parties based on religious, cultural or linguistic grounds.
*506  $bCensoring body: The administrative chamber of the Algiers Court

*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
Committee to Protect Journalists
*505  $aNote: On 13 April 1994 the independent newspaper 
"l'Independant" received a facsimile from the Ministry of 
Communication, ordering a six-month suspension of the French-language 
daily for publishing articles "undermining public order, safety, and 
the higher interests of the state." The order does not cite any 
specific articles or offer any further explanation.

971120
*041  $afre
*24510$aEl Watan
*260  $aAlgeria
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
Committee to Protect Journalists CPJ
*505  $aNote: The daily newspaper "El Watan" is threatened with 
closure. According to El Watan, its editorial director, editor-in-chief 
and a journalist were summoned for questioning in connection with an 
article that appeared on 25 May 1994 in the independent French language 
daily. The disputed article is about administrative changes within the 
office of the president. In a meeting on 26 May, two high officials 
from the Ministry of Communication told editor-in-chief Tayeb Belghiche 
and Khaled Messaoudi, who wrote the offending article, that they had 
revealed a sensitive state secret. He warned that this matter would be 
pursued in court and that, unless Khaled Messaoudi revealed his source, 
the government may consider permanently closing "El Watan".
*506  $bCensoring body: Ministry of Communication
*518  $aMay 26, 1994
*518  $3Newspaper
*651  $a5311
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aCensored
^

CPJ's Attacks on the Press 1992
*505  $aNote: Al-Mounqidh, weekly Arabic-language organ of FIS, was 
suspended by the government after it published a letter from Islamic 
Salvation Front leader Abdelkader Hachani in which he called on 
soldiers to disobey orders to shoot at demonstrators.

971122
*041  $aara
*24510$aLiberte
*260  $aAlgeria
$c1992
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
Committee to Protect Journalists
*505  $aNote: On October 2, the Algerian daily newspaper, Liberte, was 
suspended after breaking the story, on October 1, of the arrest of four 
men accused of perpetrating the bombing of the Algiers airport on 
August 26. The fifteen day suspension was ordered by the Ministry of 
the Interior which found that Liberte's publication of this news was 
"detrimental to the activities of the security services in their fight 
against terrorism."
*506  $bCensoring body: Algerian authorities
*518  $aOctober 2, 1992
*518  $3Newspaper
*651  $a5311

971123
*041  $aara
*24510$aBarid al Charq ; Essah Afa ; Le Matin ; La Nation ; Al Jazair 
al Youm
*260  $aAlgeria
$c1992
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
Committee to Protect Journalists
*505  $aNote: Barid al Charq, published in Setif, was suspended for an 
indefinite period, on September 5, by the Ministry of the Interior. An 
official ministry statement accused the paper of repeatedly publishing 
false and defamatory reports with the intent of undermining the 
security of the state. Essah Afa, a satirical independent weekly, was 
suspended indefinitely by order of the Ministry of the Interior, on 
August 19. An official statement explained that the action stemmed from 
the weekly's persistent publication of the contents of Islamic 
Salvation Front (FIS) communiques. Le Matin, La Nation, and Al Jazair 
al Youm were suspended on August 9. Presidential Decree No. 92 320, 
signed by President Ali Kafi on August 11, was used to justify the 
suspension of all six papers, even though Le Matin, La Nation, and Al 
Jazair al Youm had already been closed when it was issued. The decree 
endows the Ministry of the Interior with the power to suspend or close 
"any company, organ, establishment, or business whose nature or 
activities imperil public order, public security, the normal 
functioning of state institutions, or the higher interests of the 
country."
*506  $bCensoring body: Ministry of the Interior
*518  $aSeptember 5 1992, August 19 1992, August 9 1992
*518  $3Newspaper
*651  $a5311
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aSuspended
^

*260  $aAlgeria
$c1992
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
Committee to Protect Journalists
*505  $aNote: The independent l'Observateur, a francophone weekly, was 
suspended indefinitely, on October 22, by order of the Ministry of 
Culture and communications for incitement to violence and encouragement 
of terrorist acts. The paper published, in an article about women in 
the Islamic movement, an interview in which an anonymous woman stated 
that she personally supported armed struggle against the government.
*506  $bCensoring body: Ministry of Culture and communications
*518  $aOctober 1992

defamation of state institutions.

971126
*041  $aara
*24510$aEchourouk al-Arabi
*260  $aAlgeria
$c1992
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
CPJ's Attacks on the Press 1992
*505  $aNote: Fodhil and Bouokba, director and columnist of the 
Arabic-language independent weekly Echourouk al-Arabi, were arrested 
and charged with harming national unity and security. The charges stem 
from an article by Bouokba on June 21 in which he criticized Algeria's 
"francophone" regime on the grounds that it discriminates against the 
Arabic-speaking population; he also accused the regime of being the 
servant of the French government. Gendarmes raided the offices of 
Echourouk al-Arabi, in Algiers, and confiscated copies of every issue 
since Mr. Bouokba began writing for the paper. The paper was ordered 
indefinitely suspended. And on July 6, Fodhil and Bouokba were 
convicted and sentenced to four months in prison.
*506  $bCensoring body: Gendarmes
*518  $aJune 21, 1992
*518  $3Newspaper
*651  $a5311
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aSuspended
^

*260  $aAlgeria
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
Reporters sans frontieres
*505  $aNote: The newspaper "Le Patriote", a French-language weekly 
published in Oran, remains banned in Algeria since the first issue came 
out on 4 August 1994. It was banned by the Minister of Justice without 
any official explanation. The police who were in charge of notifying 
the editor of the paper, Abdelmalek Ouasti, of the decision, were 
informed that "Le Patriote" was being published legally. The public 
prosecutor's office and Minister of Communication apparently had both 
given their approval for the paper at the time; and in a letter dated 
12 September 1994, the Minister of Communication denies responsibility 
for the order. The matter therefore seems to have been picked up by the 
Minister of Justice.
*506  $bCensoring body: Minister of Justice
*518  $aAugust 4, 1994
*518  $3Newspaper
*651  $a5311
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^

*041  $aara
*24510$aLe Libre
*260  $aAlgeria
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
Reporters sans frontieres
*505  $aNote: On 12 November, Hichem Aboud, editor-in-chief of the 
weekly "Le Libre" was arrested and held for questioning by police. "Le 
Libre" is accused of having spread information which "questions the 
public order and counters the interests of the State," however no 
official explanation was given. Beyond the arrest of its 
editor-in-chief, the Minister of the Interior ordered the indefinite 
suspension of the weekly (Algerian law limits suspensions to six 
months).

*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
Reporters sans frontieres
*505  $aNote: On 16 November, Algerian security forces seized copies of 
two dailies in the three printing presses in the country (Algiers, Oran 
and Constantine). Approximately 25,000 copies of the Arab-language 
independent newspaper "El-Khabbar" were confiscated as they went to 
press, as well as an edition of National Liberation Front organ "El 
Hiwar". No official statementhas been issued regarding the seizures.

971134
*041  $aara
*24510$aAl-Hayat
*260  $aEgypt
$c1992
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
Reporters Sans Frontieres / CPJ's Attacks on the Press 1992
*505  $aNote: The daily "Al Hayat", which is published in London and 
printed in several capitals of Arab countries, including Cairo, was 
censored by Egyptian authorities on October 20. Reportedly the 
authorities did not accept the publication of information about the 
demonstrations of the homeless following the earthquake in Cairo. "Al 
Hayat" printed an article by the Lebanese writer Joseph Samaha, who 
wrote that the "Islamic trend has exploited the seism", especially 
since "the state proved its deficiency." The September 8 issue of the 
London-based pan-Arab daily Al-Hayat was banned from distribution in 
Egypt. It contained an article by a Sudanese scholar that critically 
examined Egyptian-Sudanese relations.
*506  $bCensoring body: Egyptian authorities

971135
*041  $aeng
*24510$aMiddle East Times
*260  $aEgypt
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
Reporters sans frontieres
*505  $aNote: The Egyptian edition of the English-language weekly 
"Middle East Times" has been prohibited from sale in Egypt for the 
first week of June. Requests by the publisher to the Ministry of the 
Interior for a justification of the ban met with no response. "Middle 
East Times" has been published in Egypt for eleven years. Since the 
beginning of 1994, nine editions of the paper have been held up or 
banned by authorities. The publishers of the newspaper report that 
these frequent measures may lead to the newspaper's eventual suspension 
of publication.
*506  $bCensoring body: Egyptian authorities

971136
*041  $aara
*10010$aFouda, Farag
*24510$aOctobre
*260  $aEgypt
$c1993
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
Reporters Sans Frontieres
*505  $aNote: By recommendation of the Islamic Research Academy of the 
Al-Azhar Religion University, the collected works of FARAG FOUDA, 
writer and editorial writer for "Octobre" who was assassinated on 8 
June 1992 by Muslim extremists, have in effect been banned on 7 January 
1993. The most recent edition of the collected works of Farag Fouda 
were withdrawn from all book stores by the "Organisme General du Livre" 
(O.G.L. - state distribution agency), only three days after 
publication. His books include 'The Absent Truth' which attacked the 
view of a Muslim state. This "banning" comes a few weeks before the 
opening of the Cairo International Book Fair, planned for January 26. 
The 1992 edition of the collection was sold out following the 
withdrawal of 8 other works by order of the Islamic Research Academy of 
the Al-Azhar Religion University. Article 103 of the Egyptian 
Constitution, which sets out the mandate of Al-Azhar, does not give the 
Islamic Research Academy the right to ban or confiscate books, limiting 
its role to having the power to recommend such activities.
*505  $aAll works by the author were banned
*506  $bCensoring body: Islamic Research Academy
*518  $aJanuary 7, 1993
*518  $3Book
*651  $a5325
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aBanned
^
971137
*041  $aira
*24510$aFarad
*260  $aIran
$c1992
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
Ministry of Culture and Islamic Guidance
*505  $aNote: Arabha, editor of the science magazine Farad, and three 
unidentified colleagues were arrested. He was accused of "printing a 
cartoon which insulted the founder of the Islamic Republic Imam 
Khomeini." The cartoon depicted a religious figure missing a hand and 
possibly half a leg as a soccer player. On September 16 Arabha was 
convicted of "acting against internal security and insulting the 
exalted Imam Khomeini" and was sentenced to six months in prison by a 
criminal court. Earlier, a colleague from Farad, named Karimzadeh and 
believed to be one of the staffers arrested with Arabha in April, was 
sentenced by an Islamic revolutionary court to one year in prison and a 
500,000 rial fine. The Ministry of Islamic Culture and Guidance has 
closed the magazine.
*506  $bCensoring body: Ministry of Culture and Islamic Guidance

contained a cartoon depicting the late Ayatollah Khomeini pointing a 
gun at a book. The drawing accompanied an interview with British 
novelist Salman Rushdie, whom Khomeini had condemned to death.

971140
*041  $aira
*10010$aSirjani, Ali-Akbar Saidi
*24510$a[Seventeen of Sirjani's books was effectively banned]
*260  $aIran
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
Human Rights Watch/Middle East
*505  $aNote: Well-known Iranian writer Ali-Akbar Saidi Sirjani was 
reported to have died of a 'heart attack' in custody on 27 November 
1994. Sirjani, 63, had been arrested on 14 March 1994 with fellow 
writer Said Niazi Kermani and accused of various charges such as 
espionage, each of which carries the death penalty in Iran. It is 
widely thought that the charges were trumped up and used as a means to 
silence Sirjani who had been very outspoken against the government's 
censorship policies. Seventeen of Sirjani's books had been effectively 
banned by the government. Sirjani's death comes just a few weeks after 
the publication of a declaration by 134 writers in Iran against 
government censorship. On 27 November 1994, the Iranian press agency, 
IRNA, issued a press release announcing that Sirjani had died of a 
"heart attack" under house arrest. Sirjani's family reported that he 
had no history of heart disease before he was imprisoned.
*506  $bCensoring body: Ministry of Culture and Islamic Guidance
*503  $aBanned before 1994
*518  $a1994
*518  $3Book
*651  $a7327
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^

authorities. Its editorial staff were arrested.

*505  $aNote: Israeli soldiers detained members of a CNN camera crew

service as they searched for wanted activists. The crew members were 
held for several hours and their video tape was confiscated. The Army 
released the tape one week later, and a censored version was aired on 
CNN on May 14.

*505  $aNote: On 14 August 1994 the Israeli Minister of the Interior

justified the suspension of the license, originally awarded on 7 
December 1993, according to Article 94/B of the state security code, 
believing the paper to be an "official organ of the Hamas terrorist 
movement."

excerpt from "A General's Bet," a book by Lebanese journalist Carol 
Daghir about General Michel Aoun, an opponent of the pro-Syrian regime 
who was forcibly ousted from his headquarters by a Syrian-Lebanese 
offensive in October, 1990. The reason given for the ban was that the 
forthcoming book had yet to be licensed for publication.

971152
*041  $afre
*24510$aLebanese Broadcasting Corporation ; France 2
*260  $aLebanon
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
Reporters sans frontieres
*505  $aNote: Minister of Information Michel Samaha ordered the 
president of the "Lebanese Broadcasting Corporation" (LBS) to suspend 
broadcast of an instalment of the program "Cercle de minuit", a 
production of the French network "France 2". The show in question 
focuses on Lebanon and features Lebanese artists and intellectuals in 
discussion with the show's host, Michel Field. The broadcast includes a 
film by a Lebanese filmmaker showing young people debating religious 
issues and the Taef peace accord. The minister justified his action by 
reference to a government edict of 24 March prohibiting independent 
media from broadcasting news bulletins or taking up political subjects. 
He telephoned the president of the "LBS" two minutes into the program 
and demanded that he terminate the broadcast.
*506  $bCensoring body: Minister of Information

971153
*041  $aara
*24510$aLe Calame
*260  $aMauritania
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
Reporters sans frontieres
*505  $aNote: All copies of the Arabic edition of the 19 May 1994 
edition of the bi-weekly "Le Calame" was seized that same day by the 
authorities. "Le Calame" is published in both French and Arabic 
editions. The magazine was seized by police as it left the state 
printing house. The seizure order was made on 18 May by the Director of 
Public Freedoms on the basis of the pre-publication copies deposited 
with the authorities and relayed to "Le Calame" by telephone. No 
written justification was given for the seizure but the Director of 
Public Freedoms is said to have explained verbally that in his view 
this edition of the newspaper "damaged state security". It appears that 
the seizure is linked to the publication in "Le Calame" of an interview 
with the president of the French non-governmental organisation Agir 
ensemble (Act Together), a Mr Barthelemy, in which he criticizes the 
Mauritanian information service.
*506  $bCensoring body: Director of Public Freedoms
*518  $aMay 19, 1994
*518  $3Magazine
*651  $a5541
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aSeized
^
971154
*041  $aara
*24510$aAl-Bayan ; Le Calame
*260  $aMauritania
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
West African Journalists' Association (UJAO)
*505  $aNote: On 30 and 31 August 1994, no. 117 of the Arab language 
version of "Al-Bayan" and no. 56 of the French "Calame" were 
confiscated in the capital of Nouakchott.  Along with "L'Eveil Hebdo" 
and "La Verite", both of these independent newspapers have been the 
object of numerous seizures. Over the past three months, at least 
twelve confiscations have occurred. "Le Calame", an independent weekly 
newspaper published in French and Arabic, was seized three times in May 
and publication was suspended during June. The 18 May 1994 Arabic 
edition of the newspaper was seized at the printer's after it published 
excerpts from a critical report by two human rights organizations,.The 
newspaper's 23 May French edition was also seized at the printer's. "Le 
Calame" was again silenced on 27 May, when its Arabic edition was 
seized at the printer's for continuing its coverage of the human rights 
abuses and Mr. Ould Dah's role in them, the editor-in-chief said. The 
23 May issue of the weekly independent newspaper "Al Bayane" was seized 
for criticizing the government's censorship of "Le Calame". All the 
seizures were carried out under the orders of the Interior Minister, 
who is in charge of the national press. Although no formal charges have 
been filed against "Le Calame", a 31 May decree issued by Mr. Ould Dah 
suspended publication of the newspaper from June 1 through June 30.
*506  $bCensoring body: Interior Minister
*505  $aSeized August 30 and 31 1994, May 18 1994, May 23 1994, May 27 
1994, Suspended June 1 - June 30 1994
*518  $a1994
*518  $3Newspaper
*651  $a5442
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aSeized
*692  $aSuspended
^
971155
*041  $aara
*24510$aL'Eveil Hebdo
*260  $aMauritania
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
Reporters sans frontieres
*505  $aNote: The 25 July 1994 edition (no. 136) of the weekly "L'Eveil 
Hebdo" (Awakening) has been seized by the authorities. A document 
notifying the newspaper of the seizure, signed by head of the Bureau of 
Political Affairs and Public Freedoms (Direction des affaires 
politiques et des libertes publiques) of the Ministry of the Interior, 
the Post and Telecommunications, was delivered to the publisher. 
According to this notification, the 25 July edition was seized under 
the provisions of article 11 of the 23 July 1991 law (no. 91.023) 
governing the media. Article 11 stipulates that "the circulation, 
distribution and sale of newspapers or writing, be they in periodical 
form or not, which are prompted by or originate from abroad or attack 
the principles of Islam or the prestige of the state, harm the common 
interest or compromise order and public security, no matter what 
language they are published in, may be banned by order of the Ministry 
of the Interior".
*506  $bCensoring body: Ministry of the Interior, the Post and 
Telecommunications
*518  $aJuly 25, 1994
*518  $3Magazine
*651  $a5541
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aSeized

*041  $aara
*24510$aAl-Nahar
*260  $aPalestine
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
Committee to Protect Journalists
*505  $aNote: On the morning of 28 July 1994, members of the 
Palestinian police's Preventative Security branch confiscated issues of 
"Al-Nahar" at Erez checkpoint, the border crossing between Israel and 
the Gaza Strip. Some journalists attribute the ban on the paper to a 
perception on the part of Palestinian authorities that "Al-Nahar" does 
not give adequate coverage to official statements of the Palestinian 
National Authority (PNA). 29 July 1994, one day after having banned the 
distribution of the daily newspaper "Al-Nahar" in the Gaza Strip, the 
Palestinian National Authority (PNA) extended the ban to the West Bank.
*506  $bCensoring body: Palestinian police's Preventative Security 
branch

971164
*041  $aara
*24510$aAl Qods ; An Nahar ; Al Aqsa ; Jerusalem Post
*260  $aPalestine
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
Reporters sans frontieres
*505  $aNote: On 28 November 1994, Palestinian police prevented the 
distribution, for approximately six hours, of at least five newspapers 
on that day in the Gaza strip. The newspapers included three 
Arabic-language dailies, "Al Qods", "An Nahar" and "Al Aqsa", the 
Arabic-language weekly "Al Manar", and the Israeli English-language 
daily "Jerusalem Post". The newspapers are believed to have been banned 
because of an "exaggerated" report of the number of people attending an 
Islamic opposition demonstration last Friday 25 November. The 
newspapers were released for distribution on the afternoon of 28 
November. The Ministry of Information of the Palestinian National 
Authority (PNA) subsequently issued a statement that no official order 
had been given to ban the distribution of any newspaper. The Ministry 
blamed the delay on unintentional technical problems and weather 
conditions.
*506  $bCensoring body: Palestinian police

971168
*041  $aara
*24510$a[Satellite dishes]
*260  $aSaudi Arabia
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
ARTICLE 19
*505  $aNote: On 10 March 1994 a decree passed by the Saudi Ministerial 
Council banned the importation, production, sale and use of satellite 
television dishes in Saudi Arabia on the grounds of protecting "the 
religious and social values of the country". Authorities have indicated 
that international television channels will be transmitted by a system 
of cable television under the control and management of the Saudi 
Ministry of Information. The decree will penalise anyone who produces, 
imports, sells or uses a satellite dish, subject to a fine of 100,000 
Saudi Riyal (
$26,600 U.S.) and confiscation of the equipment.
*506  $bCensoring body: Saudi Ministerial Council

971173
*041  $aara
$aeng
$afre
*24510$aBBC ; KUNA ; Liberation ; Le Monde ; Tunisian Press Agency (TAP)
*260  $aTunisia
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
International Federation of Journalists
*505  $aNote: Alfred Hermida, the BBC's Tunisian correspondent, was 
expelled on 18 February. Telephone and fax lines of the Kuwaiti press 
agency KUNA were cut, effectively shutting their services down. The 
following day, 19 February, most foreign press representatives were 
summoned one by one and threatened with office closures and withdrawal 
of accreditation if they failed to remain silent, or at least minimize 
their coverage of presidential candidacies. Correspondents from the BBC 
and KUNA have been sanctioned. Some foreign newspaper have been banned 
from sale, including one edition of the Parisian paper "Liberation" and 
the 10 and 18 February editions of the French daily "Le Monde". The 
foreign media has been specifically targeted, since the Tunisian media 
have been utterly silent on the events in question. This can be 
attributed partly to the dvertising monopoly which the Tunisian 
External Communications Agency has enjoyed for the past three years. 
Warnings, directives and bans are common and self-censorship is gaining 
ground. Two reporters for the Tunisian Press Agency (TAP) were 
suspended for three days for sending out foreign reports on Moncef 
Marzouki's candidacy following a "technical error". TAP employees are 
no longer allowed to freely review foreign wires, this task having been 
assigned to "trustworthy" supervisors. A new computer system allows a 
lock on information and surveillance of journalists.
*506  $bCensoring body: Government
*518  $aMarch 1994
*518  $3All media
*651  $a5362
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aCensored
^
971174
*041  $afre
*24510$aLe Monde
*260  $aTunisia
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
Reporters sans frontieres
*505  $aNote: On 18 March 1994 the Agence tunisienne de communication 
exterieure (ATCE), officially informed the French daily "Le Monde"'s 
correspondent Michel Deure that "the government has decided to ban the 
sale of 'Le Monde' in Tunisia". No reason was given for the decision. 
Previously, various editions of the newspaper had been banned from the 
country.  Authorities have also recently refused a television crew from 
the network "France 2" entry into the country in order to cover 
upcoming presidential and legislative elections. A television news 
program broadcast in Tunisia by "France 2" and "TV5 Europe", 
"Geopolis", was not broadcast when it covered the political situation 
in the country.
*506  $bCensoring body: Agence tunisienne de communication exterieure 
(ATCE)
*518  $aMarch 18, 1994
*518  $3Newspaper
*651  $a5362

^
971175
*041  $afre
*24510$aLiberation
*260  $aTunisia
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
Reporters sans frontieres
*505  $aNote: The Parisian daily newspaper "Liberation" was banned on 2 
April 1994. The decision was announced in the official government 
newspaper "La Presse de Tunis" and confirmed the following day by 
Agence tunisienne de communication exterieure (Tunisian Foreign 
Communications Agency - ATCE). According to "La Presse de Tunis", the 
authorities accuse "Liberation" of having "decided to adopt an openly 
hostile attitude towards Tunisia, its leaders and its people". In its 
23 March edition "Liberation" had published an article by a Tunisian 
intellectual which condemned the lack of democracy in Tunisia. This 
issue was not allowed to be sold in Tunisia. "La Presse de Tunis" 
claims that "Liberation" refused three requests for a right of reply 
and rejected for publication a "clarification" by the Tunisian embassy 
in France. According to "Liberation", this "clarification" was no more 
than a series of personal attacks on the author of the article and as 
such was not publishable. The banning of "Liberation" follows the 
banning of several other foreign publications in Tunisia: The French 
daily "Le Monde"; the French monthly "Le Monde diplomatique"; and the 
British daily "The Guardian". As well, many foreign journalists have 
been expelled or declared undesirable.
*506  $bCensoring body: Tunisian authorities
*518  $aApril 2, 1994
*518  $3Newspaper
*651  $a5362
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^
971176
*041  $afre
*24510$aScience et Nature
*260  $aTunisia
$c1994
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)/ 
Reporters sans frontieres
*505  $aNote: Today, 6 April 1994, the French monthly magazine "Science 
et Nature" was banned in Tunisia. It is believed that the banning is 
related to an article in the March edition of the magazine. In an 
article entitled "L'envers du decor" (The Other Side of Scenery) the 
magazine explored the contradictions between the government's "all-out 
communications strategy" and the reality of human rights and freedom of 
expression in the country. The article also cited Amnesty 
International, whose envoy Donatella Rovera was recently refused entry 
into the country. This banning follows the recent banning of several 
other foreign publications in Tunisia and the expulsion or refusal of 
entry of several foreign correspondents.
*506  $bCensoring body: Tunisian authorities
*518  $aApril 6, 1994
*518  $3Magazine
*651  $a5362

*692  $aBanned

According to Drasko Djuranovic, editor-in-chief of the "Monitor", this confiscation, which was carried out by three of the Serbian government's financial inspectors, is just one of many such seizures of the "Monitor" in recent months, copies of which are regularly "intercepted" upon their arrival in Belgrade

98019403
*041  $aeng
*24510$aPost
*260  $aZAMBIA
$c1999
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA)
*505  $aNote: The ruling Movement for Multi-party Democracy (MMD) has obtained an injunction restraining the "Post" newspaper from any further publication of articles concerning the security of Zambia and the country's stand-off with Angola. Nine "Post" journalists, including editor-in-chief Fred M'membe, were by 22 March all charged with espionage as a result of a lead story which appeared in the newspaper on 9 March. The arrest of the reporters was coupled with a siege of the "Post" editorial offices and its separately located printing press, resulting in a delay of several hours in the printing of the paper. On 10 March, police surrounded the two buildings, prevented anyone from entering or leaving, and also cut the power and water supply. On 11 March, the "Post" failed to appear on the streets of Lusaka as scheduled, the first time this had happened in its seven-year history. Those trapped in the building housing the printing press managed to print the paper, but the police prevented it from being distributed. 
*506  $bCensoring body: Movement for Multi-party Democracy (MMD)
*518  $aMarch 1999
*518  $3Newspaper
*651  $a5466
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aCensored
*70010$aM'membe, Fred
$eeditor-in-chief
^

*505  $aNote: On 14 April 1999, a Chilean judge ordered the seizure of the book's entire print run and the journalist was forced to flee the country to avoid imprisonment. On Friday 19 October 2001, the courts lifted the three-year ban.

*506  $eArticle 6(b) of the Law of State Security (LSE). This law, which dates from 1958, makes it an imprisonable offence to publish statements considered defamatory by senior officials of the government, the armed forces and the judiciary

*505  $aNote: The appellate court ordered the closure of the opposition weekly "Al-Shoura" on 16 September. The court's decision stemmed from an incident that occurred in February, when two separate versions of the paper were published under the same name, thus violating provisions of the press law. But according to journalists from "Al-Shoura", Yemeni security authorities had helped publish the second version of "Al-Shoura" as a subterfuge.

*24510$aFolha 8. Agora
*260  $aANGOLA

*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA)
*505  $aNote: On 10 December 1999, Angolan police forced two weekly independent newspapers to drop their cover stories, which criticised the government's use of oil revenues to fund the civil war in Angola. The Reuters news agency reported that police called the editors of "Folha 8" and "Agora" on 10 December, ordering them to pull the stories. While the cover of "Folha 8" advertised its intention to report on alleged government mismanagement of revenues, the first four pages were blank save for captionless photographs of oil rigs.

*24510$aTrading Post
*260  $aVANUATU
$c2000
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Pacific Islands News Association (PINA)
*505  $aNote: Vanuatu's "Trading Post" newspaper obtained and published details from a report on the sinking of a local ship in 1999, in which twenty-seven people died. The "Trading Post" was warned by both the minister for Ni Vanuatu business affairs and the Prime Minister's Office.

98019413
*041  $aeng
*24510$aTime
*260  $aINDIA
$c2000
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)
*505  $aNote: On 16 February, customs agents at the Calcutta airport blocked the distribution of 3,000 issues of "Time" magazine because they contained a one-page interview with Gopal Godse, the brother of Mohandas Gandhi's assassin, Nathuram Godse. In a letter to "Time"'s Indian distributor dated 17 February, a customs officer explained that the shipment was stopped "in order to prevent the dissemination of documents containing... [material] which is derogatory to national prestige," and stipulated that the magazines would be released only after "blackening the page containing the 'Interview' on Mahatma Gandhi appearing on page 17." "Time"'s circulation in northeast India was disrupted by the move. Subscribers' copies were delivered five days late, and vendors received their shipments several days behind schedule. The Godse interview, meanwhile, was available on "Time" magazine's Web site, and was widely circulated. 
*506  $bCensoring body: Sumit Dutta Majumdar, commissioner of customs in Calcutta
*506  $eSection 11 of the Customs Act
*518  $aFebruary 2000
*518  $3Magazine
*651  $a7425
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aCensored
^
98019414
*041  $aurd
*24510$a[All media]

$c2000
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)
*505  $aNote: In an order delivered on 25 February 2000, in response to a petition filed by the prosecution, the Justice Rehmat Hussain Jafri decided to censor media coverage of the trial of former Prime Minister Muhammad Nawaz Sharif. Journalists in Pakistan have complained that throughout the trial, military authorities have limited the press's access to Sharif, who stands accused along with six others on charges including hijacking, attempted murder, and terrorism.

98019415
*041  $amay
*24510$aHarakah
*260  $aMALAYSIA
$bPan-Malaysian Islamic Party
$c2000
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / World Association of Newspapers (WAN)
*505  $aNote: On 2 March the Home Ministry renewed "Harakah"'s publication licence for only two issues a month instead of two a week, as was the case. The newspaper had applied in December 1999 for a renewal of its licence under the Printing Press and Publications Act, which requires newspapers to secure publishing licences annually. The newspaper has been told that the restriction also applies to its Internet edition. "Harakah" is published by the Pan-Malaysian Islamic Party. This is the latest in a number of repressive actions taken against the newspaper during the past three months, including an order restricting sales to party members only, the confiscation of editions from news-stands and the prosecution of "Harakah"'s editor and printer on sedition charges over an article concerning the trial of jailed ex-Deputy Premier Anwar Ibrahim.

*24510$aAl-Wahdawi
*260  $aYEMEN
$c2000
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)
*505  $aNote: On February 22, a Sanaa court ordered the 30-day suspension of the opposition weekly Al-Wahdawi and permanently banned Al-Wahdawi contributor Jamal Amer from practicing journalism in Yemen. Amer had been charged with harming public interests, offending King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, and damaging relations between Saudi Arabia and Yemen, based on an August 10, 1999 column in which he analyzed alleged power struggles within the Saudi royal family during the summer of 1999, and predicted that they would negatively affect the ongoing Yemeni-Saudi border dispute.

*041  $afre
*24510$aLe Journal. Al-Sahiffa
*260  $aFrance
$c2000
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)
*505  $aNote: On 15 April 2000, Moroccan airport police informed staff at "Le Journal" and "Al-Sahiffa" - which are both printed in France - that the current editions of both papers were banned from distribution in Morocco. According to a Ministry of Communications statement issued later that day, the action was taken because of an article in that week's issue of "Le Journal" about the continuing dispute over the Western Sahara. The article was written by "Le Journal" director Aboubakr Jamai, based on his recent interview with Muhammad Abdelaziz, leader of the Polisario Front rebel movement, which has been fighting for the territory's independence. The banned edition of "Le Journal" also contained several other articles about the Western Sahara issue. That day's edition of "Al-Sahiffa" did not mention the Abdelaziz interview, but was banned nonetheless.
*506  $bCensoring body: Ministry of Communications

*24510$aThe Sunday Leader
*260  $aSRI LANKA
$bLeader Publications (Pvt.) Ltd.
$c2000
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)
*505  $aNote: On 22 May, dozens of police shut down a printing facility operated by Leader Publications (Pvt.) Ltd., which owns the English-language daily The Sunday Leader, in order to stop the paper's publication. Police locked the building and installed armed guards outside. The raid was prompted by a 21 May article in The Sunday Leader titled "War in Fantasyland", which lampooned the government's censorship policy. The ban on the paper is to remain in effect for six months. However, the closure of the printing press has also interrupted the production of Irida Peramuna, the Sinhala-language counterpart of The Sunday Leader, along with five other publications owned by the Leader group.

*505  $aNote: On 26 September 2000, the National Press Council, which is under the direct responsibility of the president, decreed a total media blackout on the presumed murder attempt on journalist Mohamed Taha Moamed Ahmed. *505  $aNote: The directors of Kinshasa's main independent newspapers were ordered to stop publishing information about the army and security services. The order was issued by a National Information Agency (Agence nationale de renseignements, ANR) official. Referring to a published article in the newspaper "L'Alarme", which announced that "Kabila's power will end on 15 December", the ANR official stated that independent newspapers' articles "are increasingly subversive." *24510$aDost Haber Gazetesi. Yeni Evrensel
*260  $aTURKEY
$c2000
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aNote: On 14 December 2000, while conflict in the jails was raging, the Istanbul State Security Court No 4 ordered the media not to broadcast programmes or publish articles that could be an "incitement to crime" and act as "propaganda for illegal organisations". On 20 December, the authorities carried out these threats: five publications in the northern town of Corum, including Dost Haber Gazetesi, were seized for criticising the armed forces' intervention in jails. In the first quarter of 2001, several charges were laid against the far left-wing daily Yeni Evrensel for articles published on 22 and 25 December 2000 denouncing deaths in Turkish jails.

Yet Mohamed Aghnaj, publication director of "Rissalat Al Foutouwa", is in possession of a valid receipt, dated February 1999, authorising him to publish his newspaper. Since November 2000, printers and distributors have refused to print and distribute "Rissalat Al Foutouwa". Aghnaj claims they received "instructions from above." As a result of the pressure, the newspaper's management was forced to find alternative means to print and distribute the newspaper. However, management decided to interrupt publication of "Rissalat Al Foutouwa" as of mid-April.

The main Lebanese newpapers, like "El Hayat", which address topics considered sensitive by the government, such as human rights, are regurarly censored. The daily "An Nahar" has been banned for more than ten years.

*505  $aNote: On 21 August 2001, the third edition of the book "The Temple of Fear", written by Baslangic, a journalist from the centre-left daily "Radikal", was seized following an order by Judge Dursun Ali Gumus. On 21 August, Istanbul's state prosecutor launched legal proceedings against the journalist before the Second Police Tribunal. The journalist is charged with making "unfair and false remarks against the military" and "mockery and insults against the Turkish armed forces." The journalist faces one to six years in prison, in accordance with Article 159 of the Turkish Penal Code.

98019437
*041  $aeng
*24510$aNewsweek
*260  $aUSA
$c2001
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aNote: An article on blasphemy published in the 3 September issue of "Newsweek" was censored by the Ministry of Information's press service (PID), which stated that "the article's subject matter is objectionable and may spark violence." The PID added, "the decision has been taken in the public interest" and "the magazine itself has not been banned." On 1 September, a letter was sent to the Customs department instructing them to seize copies of the magazine. The Press Information Department of Karachi (Sindh province in southern Pakistan) ordered Liberty Books Private Limited, "Newsweek"'s distributor in Pakistan, to tear out the controversial article. The article related in detail the death sentence against Younus Sheikh, accused of blasphemy for having taught his students that the prophet Mahomet was not a Muslim until he was forty years old. Liberty Books explained that the magazine would become available once the offending article was suppressed. 
*506  $bCensoring body: Ministry of Information's press service (PID)

98019439
*041  $agre
*10010$aAndroulakis, Mimis
*24510$aM to the Power of N
*260  $aGREECE
$c2000
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Greek Helsinki Monitor (GHM)
*505  $aNote: On 9 March 2000, Salonica judge Maria Robbi banned a best-selling book that was condemned by the Greek Orthodox Church because of passages about the possible sexual longings of Jesus Christ. She justified the ban as a means to prevent ''outbreaks of violence'' after religious zealots threatened to take action against the author and bookstores selling the book. The ban will remain in effect until 16 May, when a hearing is to be held on a suit to permanently halt the sale of ''M to the Power of N'', written by former communist parliament deputy Mimis Androulakis. The ban only applies to Salonica and adjacent prefectures, which are the judge's area of jurisdiction. The book will be available in the rest of Greece. At the same time, additional criminal charges for "blasphemy" have been filed by the Salonica prosecutor's office against the book's author and publisher. 
*506  $bCensoring body: Salonica judge Maria Robbi

98019442
*041  $aara
*10010$aal-`Othman, Laila 
*24510$aThe Departure
*260  $aKUWAIT
$c1984
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Human Rights Watch (HRW)
*505  $aNote: The appeals court upheld an earlier ruling that found prize-winning novelist and short story writer Laila al-`Othman's book, "The Departure," to be immoral but dropped the two month prison sentence against al-Othman and instead fined her, and her publisher Yahiya al-Rubay`an, 1000 KD (USD 3260) each for immorality. The book was also banned, although publication and distribution of it had been legal in Kuwait since 1984. The court's ruling is final. 
*506  $bCensoring body: An appeals court
*506  $eKuwait's Penal Code and Press Law that allow for sentences of up to three years in prison and a 3,000 KD fine (USD 9,780) for inciting "immoral acts" and up to one year in prison and a 1,000 KD fine (USD 3,260) for disseminating "opinions that include sarcasm, contempt, or belittling of a religion or a religious school of thought, whether by defamation of its belief system or its traditions or its rituals or its instructions."

*651  $a7332

*260  $aKUWAIT
$c2000
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Human Rights Watch (HRW)
*505  $aNote: The court overturned the two month prison sentence against Kuwait University philosophy professor Dr. `Aliya Shu`ayb for defaming religion and instead fined Shu`ayb and  her publisher Yahiya al-Rubay`an 100 KD (US$326) each for publishing Shu`ayb's collection of Arabic poetry, "Spiders Bemoan a Wound," without a permit. The book was also banned.

98019444
*041  $amay
*24510$aDetik
*260  $aMALAYSIA
$c2000
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)
*505  $aNote: On 27 March, the Home Ministry officially notified "Detik" that its publication license would not be renewed. The license had expired in December, forcing "Detik" to suspend publication and suffer major financial losses while awaiting action on its application for renewal. The action against "Detik", which has a reputation in Malaysia as a critical but independent magazine, follows the government's 1 March decision to restrict the circulation of "Harakah", a popular opposition party newspaper, from twice weekly to two editions a month.

*506  $ePrinting Presses and Publications Act of 1984: all publications are required to renew their publishing licenses annually

*505  $aNote: On the night of 6 to 7 July, police surrounded the Attakattoul printer, in Casablanca, and prevented the publication of the first issue of the weekly "Al Ousboue wa al-Sahafi". No explanation was offered by the ministry of the interior to explain this action. On 3 May, Mustapha Alaoui, the weekly's editor, was sentenced to three months' imprisonment and banned from practicing journalism for a three-year period, "for libeling" Foreign Minister Mohamed Benassa. He was pardoned by the king in late May.

*505  $aNote: Nine contributors to the opposition monthly "MoJo" are imprisoned in Burma. Three of them were arrested in May 2000. 98019457
*041  $achi
*24510$aToday China Press. Reform Press. East Wind Press
*260  $aCHINA
$c2000
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aNote: The Chinese authorities have recently announced the first "results" of an ideological campaign launched last March against "liberals and rightists". In an interview given on 13 June to the official news agency Xinhua, a director of the State Press and Publications Administration said a new "warning system" had been adopted in order to "help newspapers adhere to the guiding status of Marxism-Leninism, Mao Zedong Thought and Deng Xiaoping Theory." This campaign has already led to sanctions against a dozen newspapers and publishing houses. Some of them, including Today China Press, Reform Press and East Wind Press, were closed down. Beijing authorities also banned the publication throughout China of articles written by "liberal scholars", such as Li Shenzhi, He Jiadong and Liu Junning.
*506  $bCensoring body: Chinese authorities

*260  $aIran

*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / International Press Institute (IPI)
*505  $aNote: Iran's Press Court banned the pro-reform newspaper "Tavana". The newspaper was ordered closed on 6 August for publishing articles that allegedly defamed officials of Iran's Islamic system. Prior to its shutdown, "Tavana" had published cartoons depicting the president of Iran without his traditional robes and turban. Satire of political leaders is considered by many Shi'ite Moslem clergy to be a taboo.

*505  $aNote: On 18 August, a Baku court granted Minister for Press and Information Siruz Tabrizli's petition to ban printing and distribution of the independent tri-weekly newspaper "Uch Noqte". The court's decision was reportedly based on a new law, adopted on 13 February of this year, which stipulates that a media outlet that loses three lawsuits within twelve months can be shut down. However, this law should not have been applied to "Uch Noqte", which has lost only one case since the new law came into effect.

*24510$aK-2
*260  $aPAKISTAN ; Rawalpindi
$c2000
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Pakistan Press Foundation (PPF) 
*505  $aNote: The district magistrate of Skardu, in the northern area of Pakistan, revoked the declaration and publication licence of the weekly paper "K-2" for "promoting anti-Pakistan feelings and advocating curtailment of territories within the boundaries of the state." The magistrate issued a show-cause notice to the printer and publisher of the weekly, Raja Hussain Khan Maqpoon, for "flagrantly" violating the provisions in Sections 3-e and 3-d of Sub-Section 1 of the Press and Publications Ordinance, 1995. The publishing licence or declaration of the weekly "K-2",  was reinstated on 27 July 2001. The declaration was restored almost a year after it was revoked in August 2000 on the charge of publishing "objectionable material."
*506  $bCensoring body: The district magistrate of Skardu

98019463
*041  $aara
$afre
*24510$aLe Journal. Assahifa. Demain
*260  $aMOROCCO
$c2000
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Reporters sans frontieres (RSF) 
*505  $aNote: On 2 December, in the evening, Minister of Culture and Communications Mohamed Achaari announced "the permanent publication ban on [the] three weeklies" "Le Journal", "Assahifa" and "Demain" for having "threatened the state's stability." On 25 November and 1 December, respectively, "Le Journal" and "Assahifa" published a letter credited to former opposition figure Mohamed Basri, which stated that the Moroccan Left was involved in the attempted coup d'etat against King Hassan II in 1972, and directly implicated Youssoufi, the current prime minister and president of the Socialist Union of Popular Forces (Union socialiste des forces populaires, USFP, leftist party). Ali Lmrabet, editor of "Demain", stated that he does not understand why his magazine was also banned. "We simply noted the disclosures of 'Le Journal', as many other Moroccan newspapers had, and without publishing any additional information than the others."
*506  $bCensoring body: Minister of Culture and Communications
*506  $eArticle 77 of the Press Code, which gives the Interior Minister and the Prime Minister power to ban publications which target "the political and religious foundations of the kingdom".

The Tabriz court also sentenced Mohammed-Hossein Kouze-Gar, the newspaper's editor, to a fine of 55 million rials (about USD 31,427) for "spreading false news". The newspaper was sued by the military police of East-Azerbaijan.

*041  $aara
*24510$aAl Hadath
*260  $aJORDAN
$c2000
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aNote: On 12 December, Information Minister Rifai ordered the ban on the weekly "Al Hadath" until editor-in-chief Nidal Mansour is replaced. Mansour, who is also the president of the Center for Defending Journalists' Freedom, was expelled for life from the Jordanian Journalists' Union for "receiving foreign aid [for his organisation], thus violating Jordanian law". This decision prevents him from ever practicing his profession again because membership to the union is compulsory for journalists. According to the French news agency Agence France Presse, the minister justified his decision by explaining that "the newspaper can no longer be published since there is no editor-in-chief."

*041  $aara
*24510$aAl Alam
*260  $aMAURITANIA
$c2000
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aNote: On 14 December, in accordance with Article 11 of the press law, the Ministry of the Interior ordered the seizure of the Arabic-language weekly "Al Alam". On 16 December, the ministry banned the newspaper's publication. The incriminating issue included an article about the 28 November arrest of three officers and a second article about the recent campaign against the arrest of political opposition figures. Mohamed Mahmoud Ould Bacar, the newspaper's editor-in-chief, is the former editor-in-chief of the Arabic-language edition of the weekly "El Calame", the most frequently seized newspaper in Mauritania in 1998 and 1999. 
*506  $bCensoring body: Ministry of the Interior
*506  $eArticle 11 of the Mauritanian press law provides for "the ministry, by decree, to forbid the circulation, distribution or sale of newspapers that undermine the principles of Islam or the credibility of the state, damage the general interest or disturb public order and security"

98019467
*041  $aeng
*10010$aWest, lain
*24510$aDr lain West's Casebook
*260  $aUnited Kingdom
$bClays Limited and Little Brown and Company
$c2000
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Network for the Defence of Independent Media in Africa (NDIMA)
*505  $aNote: On 20 December 2000, Kenyan Cabinet Minister Nicholas Biwott was awarded a record KES 30 million (approx. USD 383,000) for libel in a book about the murder of the late Foreign Minister Robert Ouko. The judgement against the British authors of "Dr lain West's Casebook", which implicated the cabinet minister in a 1990 murder case, is the largest award in a libel case in the country's history. The book is banned in Kenya. In a twenty-eight-page judgement, Commissioner Visram prohibited the sale of the book within the court's jurisdiction. The two authors must also pay the costs of the suit. Biwott may enforce the award through the United Kingdom High Court, which would issue a decree forcing West and Stern to pay. The 20 December ruling arose from an earlier suit against the book's publishers, Clays Limited and Little Brown and Company, and two Kenyan bookshops which had sold the book. The case was combined with the one against West and Stern.
*506  $bCensoring body: Commissioner Visram
*518  $a2000
*518  $3Book
*651  $a5234
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
*70010$aStern, Chester
$eco-author
^
98019468
*041  $aira
*24510$aKiyan
*260  $aIRAN
$c2001
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Human Rights Watch (HRW)
*505  $aNote: The closure of Kiyan, a ten-year-old independent journal that specialized in issues of philosophy, religion, and literature, was announced by state-controlled radio and television on January 17. Many of Iran's leading intellectual and artistic figures contributed to the journal during the decade it published. The magazine presented diverse interpretations of Islamic law and promoted open debate on religious and philosophical questions. The summary closure was ordered by Saeed Mortazavi, a judge in Branch 1410 of the Tehran General Court, which deals with press offenses. The order was based on a complaint from Abbasali Alizadeh, the head of the Justice Department in Tehran, in his capacity as general prosecutor. Under Iranian law, only the Press Supervisory Board within the Ministry of Culture and Islamic Guidance can order the closure of newspapers and magazines. The judiciary in this case cited Article 156 (5) of the Constitution, which it claimed empowered it to take appropriate measures in order to prevent crime.
*506  $bCensoring body: Saeed Mortazavi, a judge in Branch 1410 of the Tehran General Court
*506  $eArticle 156 (5) of the Constitution
*518  $aJanuary 2001

98019486
*041  $aara
*24510$aRai al-Shaab
*260  $aSUDAN
$c2001
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aNote: The daily "Rai al-Shaab" was closed on 22 February by court order. On newsstands since 6 February, "Rai al-Shaab" was the first daily published by an opposition party in Sudan since Omar el-Bashir's coup d'etat in 1989. The daily was published by the Popular National Congress (PNC) party, run by el-Tourabi, the regime's former ideologue, ousted from positions of power in December 1999 by President el-Bashir.

98019487
*041  $aira
*24510$aHarim
*260  $aIRAN
$c2001
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aNote: On 8 March 2001, the political weekly "Harim" was suspended by the judiciary for "defaming" President Mohammad Khatami. In an article entitled "The Slogans Of Mr. Khatami", the newspaper mocked the president who promised "to institute the rule of law and civil society in Iran" during the 1997 presidential campaign. Hassan Akhtari, the newspaper's editor, may soon be prosecuted. 
*506  $bCensoring body: Iranian judiciary

98019488
*041  $aara
*24510$aEl Mustaqilla. Salama
*260  $aParis ; London
$c2001
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aNote: The last issue of the fortnightly "Salama", published in Paris, was banned in Tunisia. The issue, which contained an article about the status of women, pointed out "the limits of freedom of expression for Tunisian women", among other issues. The preceding issue, also banned, featured an article titled "Tunisia: the paradox of a democracy a minima". The most recent issue of the Arabic weely "El Mustaqilla", published in London, was also banned. Two articles dealt with human rights in the country. In both cases, the authorities did not give any explanations for the bans. Numerous foreign publications are still banned in Tunisia, including the French newspapers ("Liberation", "Charlie Hebdo", "La Croix", "Le Canard enchaine" and "L'Humanite"), privately-owned Algerian newspapers and certain privately-owned Moroccan newspapers. Moreover, authorised newspapers such as "Le Monde", "Jeune Afrique-L'Intelligent" and "Courrier international" are censored when they deal with the issue of human rights in Tunisia. The press on the Internet is also targeted
*506  $bCensoring body: Minister of the Interior
*518  $aMarch 2001
*518  $3Newspaper
*651  $a5362

*692  $aCensored

98019490
*041  $atur
*24510$aYeni Evrensel
*260  $aTURKEY
$c2000
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aNote: The appeals court confirmed the seven-day ban (pronounced by the Istanbul State Security Court Number 3) against Yeni Evrensel. In an article published on 8 January 2000, the fourth anniversary of the murder of reporter Metin Goktepe, the paper denounced the impunity received by two Istanbul police civil servants, Orhan Tasanlar and Kemal Bayrak, who were charged in connection with the murder. The paper was accused of making the police a target for illegal organisations. The newspaper's owner, Fevzi Saygili, and its editor-in-chief, Ali Karatas, were fined 475 (about 540 euros) and 235 million (about 267 euros) pounds.

98019491
*041  $aara
*24510$aHuman rights newspaper
*260  $aYEMEN
$c2001
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aNote: On 24 April the first issue of a human rights monthly was banned by the information minister. Ministry officials said the publication violated the press law. They did not elaborate. Following the ban, the newspaper was removed from newsstands. The monthly, published by Mohammed Naji Alaw, a member of the Institution of Human Rights Activists, was the first regular publication of its kind in Yemen. Yemen's press law exempts organisations and political parties from applying for a publication permit.

*24510$aSolidarite Paalga
*260  $aIvory Coast
$c2001
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aNote: In a 12 April 2001 letter, CNP decided to suspend the bi-monthly "Solidarite Paalga" until further notice. CNP cites three reasons for this decision: the nationality of publishing director Nicolas Sahouidi, who is from Burkina Faso, a complete disrespect of the legal deposit system and the lack of professional journalists amongst the editorial staff. On 3 May 2001, the CNP lifted the suspension against the publication.

98019494
*041  $aara
*24510$aAl-Tadamon al-Arabi wal-Douali
*260  $aLebanon
$c2001
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aNote: In April 2001, the Kuwaiti embassy in Lebanon informed Mona Chatilla, owner and editor-in-chief of the magazine "Al-Tadamon al-Arabi wal-Douali", that the most recent issue of her newspaper had been seized at the Kuwait City airport. She was also told that the information minister had ordered that this publication be banned by the emirate. The Kuwaiti authorities also refused to renew accreditation of the newspaper's Kuwaiti correspondent, Oulfat Farid, and told the editor-in-chief that she is now banned from visiting the country. A picture of Saddam Hussein and his son Qoussai were on the front page of the last issue of "Al-Tadamon al-Arabi wal-Douali". "Al-Tadamon al-Arabi wal-Douali" is a Cyprus-based fortnightly published and printed in Lebanon. Distributed in a dozen Arab countries, this newspaper is today forbidden in Saudi Arabia, Algeria and Libya.

98019500
*041  $afre
*24510$aLa Libre Afrique
*260  $aDEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO
$c2001
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Journaliste en danger (JED)
*505  $aNote: On 10 May 2001, Minister of Communications and Press Kikaya bin Karubi banned the publication of the newspaper "La Libre Afrique", as well as its supplement "Le Derby" and its satirical supplement "Incognito" throughout the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). The minister justified his decision on the fact that "the administrative documents received by the newspaper 'La Libre Afrique' and its supplements 'Le Derby' and 'Incognito' were issued on the basis of false statements made to the administration with regard to the newspaper's and its printer's addresses, as well as the publication director's status as a professional journalist." Moreover, Kikaya added that "'La Libre Afrique' does not fulfil its legal obligation to publish the name or the address of the printer in each copy of the newspaper, which would allow for the verification of the newspaper's administrative and jurisdictional acts." 
*506  $bCensoring body: Minister of Communications and Press
*506  $eLaw no. 96/002 of 22 June 1996, which covers the exercise of press freedom in the DRC
*518  $aMay 2001
*518  $3Newspaper
*651  $a5123
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aCensored

98019501
*041  $aeng
*24510$aThe Nation. The Guardian
*260  $aSWAZILAND
$c2001
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aNote: On 22 May 2001, the minister of information banned "The Nation" and "The Guardian" for the second time because "they are prejudicial and/or potentially prejudicial to the interests of the public order in that they are not duly registered and/or are not operating in accordance with the applicable laws of the Kingdom of Swaziland." Previously, on 4 May, the minister had banned the two publications known for their critical tone toward the authorities. But on 18 May, the High Court of Swaziland judged this ban illegal in the case of "The Nation" because the minister gave no reasons for his decision. Attorney General Phesheya Dlamini appealed the High Court's decision. Despite the Court order allowing the magazine to be published, on 22 May, police confiscated the last edition of "The Nation", which is printed in South Africa. The second ban was announced before the High Court could rule on the case of "The Guardian", during a hearing where "The Nation" had appealed for an order banning the police from confiscating the magazine. On 24 May, the High Court ruled that the police action was justified. The High Court will rule on "The Guardian" case soon
*506  $bCensoring body: minister of information
*518  $aMay 2001
*518  $3Newspaper
*651  $a5460
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aCensored
*74000$aThe Nation
*74000$aThe Guardian
^

98019503
*041  $aeng
*24510$aThe Namibian
*260  $aNAMIBIA
$c2001
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA)
*505  $aNote: Namibia's ruling party, the South West Africa People's Organisation (SWAPO) has joined the government in an advertising and purchasing ban on "The Namibian" newspaper, because of the newspaper's alleged "hostile attitude" towards government. The government decided in December 2000 to stop advertising in "The Namibian", saying that the newspaper had made "unwarranted criticism" of its policies. In addition, President Sam Nujoma issued an order in late May, forbidding all government departments from buying the newspaper.
*506  $bCensoring body: Namibia's ruling party, the South West Africa People's Organisation (SWAPO) and the government

*10010$aSmith Hempstone
*24510$aRogue Ambassador
*260  $aUSA
$c2001
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Network for the Defence of Independent Media in Africa (NDIMA)
*505  $aNote: On 4 September 2001, a High Court in Nairobi extended an interim injunction restraining Text Book Centre from further distributing the book "Rogue Ambassador" by former United States Ambassador to Kenya Smith Hempstone. Commissioner of Assize Jeanne Gacheche also blocked the bookseller's agents and servants from further circulating or selling copies of the book, whose contents are the subject of a defamation suit filed by Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi and Cabinet Minister Nicholas Biwott.

The newspaper contained statements by Spanish Foreign Affairs Minister Josep Pique, to the effect that "there was evidence of collusion between the Moroccan police and (immigration) mafias."

*24510$aLe Gri-Gri International
*260  $aParis ; France
$c2001
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aNote: On 18 October 2001, Mr. Barre, head of Sogapresse, asked that shipments of "Le Gri-Gri International" be stopped. Yet, a week earlier, Sogapresse had ordered more copies of the newspaper because of high demand for it in Gabon. National Chief of Police Jean-Claude Labouba summoned Barre on 15 October. Labouba told him to stop distributing "Le Gri-Gri International", explaining that this was on the instructions of the Ministry of the Interior. Criminal Investigation Department officers seized the last copies of the newspaper that were available in kiosks on 12 October. They did not have a warrant to carry out the seizure.

*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aNote: The 31 October 2001 issue of the French weekly "Le Canard enchaine" has been held back by the distributor, Sochepresse, since the evening of 31 October. The issue includes an article titled "His Majetski M6", which comments on Jean-Pierre Tuquoi's most recent book about Morocco, "The Last King" (published by Grasset). The journalist notably wrote, "After a two and a half year reign, his son has not done very much, except restrain the press, yield to the Islamists on women's rights, manage his immense fortune and play sports...."

*24510$aTempo
*260  $aINDONESIA
$c1998
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Institut Studi Arus Informasi (ISAI)
*505  $aNote: Staff at Tempo, Indonesia's leading weekly news magazine when it was banned in 1994, announced in October 1998, that the publication would return to the newsstands. Tempo had a circulation of some 180,000 copies when the Suharto government closed it down on June 21, 1994, citing vague "substantive" editorial reasons. Tempo's chief editor Gunawan Mohamad said that until now, the precise reason for the 1994 ban remained unknown, but he speculated that the final blow might have been a report critical of the purchase by the government of 39 old East German navy vessels.
*506  $bCensoring body: president Suharto's administration
