*10010$aMatiba, Kenneth
*24510$aReturn to Reason
*260  $aKENYA
$c1993
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Network for the Defence of Independent Media in Africa (NDIMA)
*505  $aNote: In November 1998, A Court of Appeal decision cancelled the publication ban which was imposed by the government after the book's launching in November 1993. The government banned the book on 14 January 1994, prohibiting its publication after it had already sold over one thousand copies. The judges allowed publication of the controversial book five years after the ban's introduction, saying it contains a concise record of Kenya's political, economic and human rights history, and materials from articles published in the local media and from such sources as the Controller, Auditor-General and other government departments, as well as NGOs.

On 24 January 1996, "Majira" was banned from the island when the government of Zanzibar accused the paper of publishing "seditious and malicious" articles against the ruling CCM party. The Zanzibar Minister of Information, Youth, Tourism and Culture, Issa Mohammed Issa, announced the ban on state controlled radio and cited a number of articles that questioned President Amour's political conduct after the October 1995 general elections.

*260  $aEGYPT
$bSawt Al-Ummah Publishing and Journalism House
$c1999
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Egyptian Organization for Human Rights (EOHR)
*505  $aNote: The Higher Press Council's cancelled the license of Sawt Al-Ummah newspaper, published by Sawt Al-Ummah Publishing and Journalism House. The decree was made on the grounds that the publishing house had made changes to the company's structure, on which the license had been issued on 29 March 1997. These changes included the names of the shareholders and the company's board, after a number of shareholders had sold their shares to others and a new board was elected in a general shareholders assembly on 9 February 1999.

*505  $aNote: Well ahead of the tenth anniversary of the student movement at Tiananmen Square, the government took steps to prevent attempts to commemorate it and to restrict the availability of news about any such events. In April, the Hong Kong-based newspaper "Ming Pao" reported that the Communist Party committee in southern Guangdong province had "banned all articles about the 4 June events and improper use of material taken from the internet". The committee's directive advised newspaper executives to "restrict the number of articles written by commentators", in case their opinions differed from those of the party.

*505  $aNote: On 9 June 1999, the daily and weekly Serbian editions of "Nezavisne Novine", a newspaper which is close to the government of Prime Minister Milorad Dodik, were seized at the border by Serbian police. The next day, copies of the daily edition were seized once again. According to Gradisa Katic, the editor-in-chief of "Nezavisne Novine", "the chief reason [for the seizure] is that our newspaper quotes a number of politicians who stated that the Belgrade regime was going to surrender." The newspaper has often included columns written by Serbian opponents to the regime of Slobodan Milosevic

98019534
*041  $atur
*10010$aMater, Nadire
*24510$aMehmed's Book: Soldiers Who have Fought in the Southeast Speak Out
*260  $aTURKEY
$bMetis Publishers
$c1999
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)
*505  $aNote: On Wednesday 23 June 1999 an Istanbul
court banned distribution of the book "Mehmed's Book: Soldiers Who have Fought in the Southeast Speak Out," written by Turkish journalist Nadire Mater, a freelance reporter with Inter Press Service (IPS). The court ruled that the book, first published in April 1999, had insulted the military and thus violated Article 159 of the Turkish Penal Code. Copies of the book, which consists of a series of interviews with forty-two retired Turkish soldiers who have fought in the civil conflict in southeastern Turkey, were confiscated by police from the book's Istanbul-based publisher, Metis Publishers. Since April, four editions of the book have been printed and around 9,000 copies sold. Mater also faces possible criminal charges under Article 159.
*506  $bCensoring body: Istanbul court
*506  $eArticle 159 of the Turkish Penal Code
*518  $aJune 1999
*518  $3Book
*651  $a8048
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^

*505  $aNote: On 29 June, the London-based Palestinian daily was banned from entering Syria. The ban was caused by a 28 June harsh editorial criticising Syria's failure to defend Lebanon during last week's Israeli air raids. The daily pointed out that "no single missile was fired against the Israeli warplanes by the Syrian air force which is supposed to defend Lebanon under the agreement which justifies their presence in Lebanon."

"Nachnyem s Ponedelnika", published in Almaty (the former capital of Kazakhstan), has been in existence for six years and has a large circulation.

*24510$aSalam
*260  $aIRAN
$c1999
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aNote: On 7 July, the daily Salam was suspended for criticising a bill which was to toughen penalties against the press. This closure led to a number of confrontations between students and law enforcement officials in the country's main cities. On 4 August, Salam was permanently suspended. Furthermore, Morad Veissi, a "Salam" journalist, was arrested on 7 July.

*260  $aTANZANIA
$c1999
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA)
*505  $aNote: The government of Tanzania has banned the daily Kiswahili-language newspaper "Majira"  from being published, printed and circulated in Tanzania for seven days, effective 22 July 1999. The move followed a story carried in the newspaper's 22 July edition which reported on proposed hefty pay packages for ministers and senior government executives beginning this fiscal year.

*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aNote: On 24 July 1999, despite the authorisation delivered earlier, "The Independent" was suspended on the orders of the Ministry of Justice because of so-called "irregularities on its enrolment in the Trade Department." In its first issue, on 5 July, "The Independent" had published a statement by the United Democratic Party (UDP, opposition) describing President Yahya Jammeh as "the richest person in the region" and the "most corrupt head of state in Africa".

*505  $aNote: On 26 July, the National Press Council ordered the daily to be suspended because of articles critical of the government's policies. It was the fourth time that a suspension had been ordered since the beginning of the year: on 11 January it was suspended for two days, on 22 June for another two days, and on 5 July for five days.

98019542
*041  $aeng
*10010$aRoy, Arundhati
*24510$aThe Greater Common Good
*260  $aIndia
$c1999
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)
*505  $aNote: In Gujarat State, virtually all bookstores have pulled copies of Roy's book for fear of violent reprisal. Activists from the two most powerful political parties in India, the Congress Party and the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), held demonstrations condemning Roy for her anti-Narmada views. On 22 June, members of the youth wing of the Congress Party burned several copies of "The Greater Common Good", and Youth Congress President Himattsinh Patel threatened that "If within the next 24 hours, all [Roy's] irresponsible, anti-development books are not withdrawn from the shelves, the bookstores will have to face the wrath of angry Youth Congressmen." The BJP's youth wing held a similar demonstration on Saturday 24 July. 
*506  $bCensoring body: Bookstores, Congress Party, Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP)

*505  $aNote: On 27 July 1999, police officers seized copies of the fifth issue of the monthly, which focuses on economic issues, in Abidjan kiosks. The security forces did not have a warrant permitting this seizure, and refused to answer  questions by the press about the operation. The monthly included a feature on Cte d'Ivoire and a front-page headline titled: "Disinformation, manipulation, corruption, embezzlement, is the Bedie System at death's door?"

*260  $aIRELAND

*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / International Press Institute (IPI)
*505  $aNote: The Censorship of Publications Board voted in favour of the prohibition order against "In Dublin" under the Censorship of Publications Act, 1946, at a meeting on 18 April 1999. Following meetings with the publishers of "In Dublin", the board announced on 11 August that it had decided to ban the publication for six months. The ban prohibits the sale and distribution in Ireland of any issue of "In Dublin" on or after 10 August.

*24510$a[twenty-seven newspapers]

$c2000
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / World Association of Newspapers (WAN)
*505  $aNote: On 12 January the government announced that it had "punished" twenty-seven newspapers, closing some down, for violating press regulations and printing fabricated or sensationalist stories. The State Press and Publication Administration stated that it had targetted newspapers that had published stories with "political errors" or fabricated news or had published supplements without permission. The newspapers concerned were not identified and no further details of the punishment were given.

*24510$aSwazi Observer. Weekend Observer. Intsatseli
*260  $aSWAZILAND
$c2000
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)
*505  $aNote: On February 17, the state-owned Swazi Observer media group, which includes the daily "Swazi Observer", the "Weekend Observer", and the weekly "Intsatseli" was ordered closed. This decision appears to be the latest and most serious attempt to punish the Swazi Observer's editorial staff for refusing to reveal confidential sources of information contained in critical reports on Swazi police activities.

98019561
*041  $amay
*24510$aDetik
*260  $aMALAYSIA
$c2000
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aNote: On 25 March the government decided not to renew the licence of the bimonthly "Detik". Since December, the newspaper's editors have been waiting for a decision from the ministry. According to Malaysian press law, all the printed media must request the renewal of their publishing permits every year. The editor of "Detik" has been accused by the authorities of failing to respect the conditions of the magazine's permit. In reality, the authorities are upset because he appointed a chief editor who was not favourable to the government. 
*506  $bCensoring body: Home Affairs Minister

$c2000
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Human Rights Watch (HRW)
*505  $aNote: Tunisian authorities closed down Editions Aloes, an independent publishing house in Tunis. Police sealed off the organization's office on the evening of Monday, April 10. Editions Aloes, founded and directed by longtime human rights activist Sihem Ben Sedrine, specializes in works of philosophy, art, and natural history, and has become a meeting place for Tunisian writers, artists, and human rights defenders.

With a circulation of 20,000 and freely available in Beijing, the weekly focuses particularly on cultural and entertainment news. A communique issued by the authorities on April 23 and published in the local press added that the newspapers had been closed in order to "prevent them from committing new offenses, from affecting society's opinions, and arousing concern among the people."

98019569
*041  $aaze
*24510$aBakinski Boulvard. Monitor Weekly
*260  $aAZERBAIJAN
$c2000
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aNote: On 16 May 2000 the weekly "Monitor Weekly" was suspended by the country's Economic Court, further to the filing of a complaint by a private company, which accused the newspaper of "propagating false information". On 7 May, the Ministry of Finance's services had already closed the offices of "Monitor Weekly". The next day, Baku Printing Press, the largest private printing house in the country, and the offices of the newspaper "Babinski Boulvard" were also closed. The authorities had justified the closures by alluding to financial impropriety in the accounts of the Centre for Geopolitical Research (CGR), a company cofounded by Elmar Huseinov, the publisher of "Monitor Weekly".

*041  $aira
*24510$aBayan
*260  $aIRAN
$c2000
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aNote: On 25 June, an Iranian religious court ordered the closure of the daily "Bayan" for an indefinite period because it had "broken the laws of Islam" and "published false information". The newspaper, whose editor is Hojatoleslam Ali-Akbar Mohtashemi, an adviser to President Khatami and a former interior minister, was launched in early December 1999 by staff of the reformist daily "Salam", which was also closed down by the authorities in July 1999
*506  $bCensoring body: Iranian religious court

*260  $aCote d'Ivoire
$c2000
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)
*505  $aNote: Le Liberal did not appear on July 7. The paper was ordered closed for an indefinite period by the junta in retaliation for the paper's supposed affiliation with the Rally of Republicans (RDR) and a July 6 front-page article headlined "12,000 Mutineers Want 78 Billion Francs." The report, which clearly alluded to the July 4 unrest, charged that General Geui's regime was at the mercy of Cote d'Ivoire 12,000-man armed forces.

*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aNote: On 25 July 2000, the Iranian courts ordered the suspension of the weekly "Gunagoun". The authorities claim that this publication was created in order to replace suspended reformist newspapers, something which is forbidden by the press law. Furthermore, on 24 July, the weekly's editor-in-chief, Fatmeh Farahmandpour, was summoned to court for "insulting government officials", "anti-islamic propaganda", and "spreading false reports".

98019575
*041  $aeng
*24510$aFrontier Post
*260  $aPAKISTAN ; Peshawar
$c2001
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Pakistan Press Foundation (PPF)
*505  $aNote: On 29 January 2001, police in Peshawar raided the offices of the daily "Frontier Post", arrested five employees, sealed the offices and closed down the newspaper. On 30 January, a mob set the newspaper's printing press ablaze for publishing a blasphemous letter, police and witnesses said. The attackers set the newsprint rolls and the machinery inside on fire and the press was totally gutted. The official action and the mob attack was in reaction to a blasphemous letter published in its Letters to the Editor column, in the opinion page of the paper, that accused Prophet Muhammad of lewd behavior and victimising Jews.
*506  $bCensoring body: police in Peshawar

*24510$aAl-Shomou
*260  $aYEMEN
$c2001
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aNote: On 30 January 2001, a court ordered the one-month closure of the weekly "Al-Shomou" for libelling Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak. On 8 November, two complaints were filed by the Ministry of Information about articles published in the paper in October which were regarded as libellous towards Mubarak and several Yemeni ministers. The paper accused Mubarak of being "an accomplice of Israel and the United States as regards the Arabs and nationalist cause". In addition to the one-month closure, the weekly was fined 10,000 riyals (approx. US$61; 89 euros).
*506  $bCensoring body: Ministry of Information

*24510$aHurriyet. Uch Nogte
*260  $aAZERBAIJAN
$c2001
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / ARTICLE 19
*505  $aNote: A new tax code levying an 18% duty on imported commodities, came into force on 1 January 2001. According to the journalists' association, Yeni Nasil, the price per tonne of news print has risen to between USD 1000-1200 and at least two newspapers, Hurriyet and Uch Nogte, have already been forced to halt publication. Editors and journalists claim that the shortage of news print has been artificially created by the authorities as a means to force the closure of independent publishers.

*24510$aAsaba
*260  $aKYRGYZSTAN
$bUchkun Publishing House
$c2001
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aNote: On 6 March, the Leninskyi tribunal in Bishkek ordered the publishing house to cease publishing the newspaper "Asaba". The decision follows the 20 October 2000 sentencing of the publication to pay a fine of 5 million soms (approx. USD 101,700; 105,000 euros), for defamation. Turdakun Usubaliev, a member of parliament who is former secretary-general of the Kyrgyz Communist Party and close to President Akayev, had accused the newspaper of regularly "attacking his dignity" over the course of the last eight years, and was seeking fifty million soms in compensation (approx. USD 1,017,150; 1,050,000 euros).

*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aNote: The independent weekly "Res Publica" was barred from publishing on 21 February. The paper was unable to pay the 200,000 som fine (approx. USD 4,070; 4,500 euros) it received at the conclusion of a defamation trial. The suit was brought against the paper in 1998 by Amandek Karypkulov, president of the national radio-television station (KTR), following the publication of an article in which he was accused of misappropriating three million soms (approx. USD 61,000; 67,500 euros)

*505  $aNote: On 29 March 2001, Spanish journalist Rei, director of the pro-independence magazine "Ardi Beltza" ("black sheep" in the Basque language), was indicted by judge Garzon for "belonging to the armed organisation ETA". Judge Garzon justified his decision to close the magazine "Ardi Beltza" because it is ''an instrument and vehicle for the assumed criminal activities'' of its director.

*505  $aNote: One of Ethiopia's most popular newspapers has been closed down. "Eletawi Addis" had only been in circulation for eight months, but rapidly became one of the most respected newspapers in the country. The closure followed a dispute between the newspaper's editor and owner over the reporting of a dispute within Ethiopia's main political party.

*24510$aSevodnya. Itogi
*260  $aRUSSIA
$c2001
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / International Press Institute (IPI)
*505  $aNote: The state-linked natural gas company, Gazprom, was engaged in a hostile takeover of Media-Most, citing unpaid debts as the reason. Gazprom is the main creditor of Media-Most, Russia's most influential media company outside state control. On 16 April, Gazprom, together with an individual shareholder in the Media-Most owned publishing house Sem Dnei, announced that it would no longer finance daily "Sevodnya", a decision which effectively closed down the newspaper. The following day, Sem Dnei said that it had fired the editorial staff of the weekly magazine "Itogi".

*24510$aLa Libre Afrique. Le Derby. Incognito
*260  $aDEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO
$c2001
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / International Press Institute (IPI)
*505  $aNote: Minister of Communications and Press Kikaya bin Karubi banned the publication of the newspaper "La Libre Afrique", as well as its supplements "Le Derby" and "Incognito" in the DRC on 10 May. The minister justified his decision by saying, "The administrative documents received by the newspaper 'La Libre Afrique' and its supplements 'Le Derby' and 'Incognito' were issued on the basis of false statements made to the administration with regard to the newspaper's and its printer's addresses, as well as the publication director's status as a professional journalist." Kikaya added that "La Libre Afrique" failed to fulfil its legal obligation to publish the name and the address of the printer in each copy of the newspaper, "which would allow for the verification of the newspaper's administrative and jurisdictional acts."
*506  $bCensoring body: Minister of Communications and Press

98019586
*041  $aaze
*24510$aImpul
*260  $aAZERBAIJAN
$c2001
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Committee to Protect Journalists
(CPJ)
*505  $aNote: Print media outlets are adjusting to a June presidential decree requiring the press to print exclusively in the Latin script. The decree was intended to reduce the dominance of the Russian language in Azerbaijan. Josef Stalin imposed the Cyrillic script, which is derived from Russian, on Azerbaijan in 1939. Since then, most Azeri-language newspapers in the country have been printed in Cyrillic. One independent weekly tried to defy the decree and continue publishing in Cyrillic. But the August 9 edition of Impul's never appeared on newsstands because the government pressured the paper's printing house to block the issue. Officials summoned Impul's owner, Xan Husseyn Aliyev, to the Baku prosecutor's office and gave him an official warning for violating the regulation. The newspaper has since ceased publication.
*506  $bCensoring body:

USD 17,400; 17,000 euros) in damages to the Baku mayor.

*505  $aNote: 17 September 2001, the Narimanov District Court of Baku considered the claim of the head of the Presidential Administration, Ramiz Mehdiyev, against the newspaper "Milletin sesi" (Voice of the Nation). An employee of the newspaper and story writer, Gulnaz Qamberli, received a three month conditional sentence as well. Shahbaz Khuduoglu was arrested immediately in a hall of the court. In another session of the same court, the newspaper "Milletin sesi" was ordered closed.

*24510$aThe News. Monrovia Guardian
*260  $aLIBERIA
$c2001
*500  $aSource: IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange) / Reporters sans frontieres (RSF)
*505  $aNote: On 20 November 2001, policemen visited the offices of the private daily "The News". They did not have a warrant but ordered the newspaper's personnel to leave the premises. A police officer explained to one of "The News"'s editors that the measure was linked to the newspaper's unpaid taxes. That same day, policemen arrested Tarpeh, chairman of "The News"'s board of directors. The "Monrovia Guardian" was also closed for the same reason. The Ministry of Finance said the two publications had not settled their taxes with the government.

*24500$aAarhus Ekko
*260  $aAArhus
*300  $a2-10 pages
*310  $aPublished monthly Nov. 1941-May 1945
*362  $aVol. 1, no. 1 (1941)-vol. 1, no. 37 (1945)
*500  $aSource: The Royal Library, Denmark
*505  $aContents: Danish and foreign news with local news
*505  $aThe newspaper, published by "D.K.P." in Aarhus, was a 
continuance of a legal newspaper with the same name. In spite of 
arrests and crack-downs, partly imposed by the Danish police and later 
the Gestapo, with very few exceptions, the newspaper was published 
every month, and even daily during the major strike in Aug. 1943. Three 
places of publishing were seized by the Gestapo. On 21 June 1944 more 
than 40 co-workers were arrested. From 1941 to 1945 five editors and 
over two hundred co-workers, distributors and money collectors were 
arrested. Four died in concentration camps
*503  $aCirculation: 600 printed, a total of 125.000 copies of 62 
issues. Not all issues were distributed
*506  $eIllegal newspaper produced during the German occupation of 
Denmark 1940-1945

*24500$aAarhus nyt
*260  $aAArhus
$c1942
*300  $a4 pages
*310  $aPublished twice in 1942
*362  $aVol. 1, no. 1 (1942)-vol. 1, no. 2 (1942)
*500  $aSource: The Royal Library, Denmark
*505  $aContents: Local news
*505  $aPublished by "Frit Danmark" in Aarhus. The newspaper ceased its 
publication after the second volume in Oct. 1942. In Dec. the same year 
the editor and several of the co-workers were arrested, and were 
sentenced up to 6 months in prison by the Danish Court. One of the 
editors, Viggo Emil Hansen, continued the illegal work after his 
release and was arrested again 1 Feb. 1944 by the Gestapo. He was 
deported to a German concentration camp where he died 28 Nov. the same 
year. For further details see "Frit Danmark", "Budstikken" and "Frit 
Dannmarks Nyhedstjeneste, Aarhus", which indirectly were a continuation 
of the newspaper.
*503  $aCirculation: 200-300 printed, a total of 500 copies of 2 
issues. Not all issues were distributed

independent press by the Nigerian government, and discusses how to 
safeguard media freedom during the "transition to civilian rule"

*300  $a320 p.
*500  $aSource: National library of Lithuania: From the series of 
publications on Lithuanian libraries; historical sources and historical 
research : Forbidden Authors and Publications, The first years of the 
Soviet occupation 15.6.1940-21.6.1941, by Klemensas Sinkevicius. 
Published in Vilnius 1994. Original  title: Uzdrausti autoriai ir 
leidiniai: pirmieji sovietinos okupacijos metai, 
1940.06.15-1941.06.21.- Vilnius, 1994.
*506  $aCensored or destroyed were all national or foreign publications 
considered to be harmful to the Communist Party and to the teachings of 
Marx, Lenin and Stalin.
$bCensoring body: GLAVLIT (The Supreme Board of Publishing and 
Literature, Council of Ministers of the Lithuanian SSR)
$eGrounds of censorship: Political.
*520  $aThis translation of the title indicates the content of the

was censored without any explanation. The Ministry of the Interior 
refused to turn over the proof of receipt to the editors. On the same

article on serial rapes

*24500$aTobia. Fiyameta. Urji. Beza. Addis lesan
*260  $aEthiopia
$b[Tobia ; Fiyameta ; Urji ; Beza ; Addis Lesan]
*500  $aSource: Reporters sans frontieres (RSF) / IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)
*505  $aSince September 1997, the repression against journalists and 
newspapers has led 21 journalists to jail and shut down five weeklies. 
During the week of 12 January, two private dailies disappeared from 
news stands: "Fiyameta", which is close to the opposition, ceased 
publishing a few days after the unexplained arrest of its editor in 
chief, Dawit Kebede. The same thing happened to "Urji", a newspaper 
close to the Oromo Liberation Front (OLF) guerrilla movement, whose 
editor, Wakshu Bacha, and deputy editor, Alemu Tolessa, were arrested 
on 23 December 1997
*505  $aShut down by the government
*518  $aJanuary 16, 1998
$3Newspaper

*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aClosed

9908731
*041  $aira
*24500$aTous
*260  $aIran
$b[Tous]
*500  $aSource: Committee to protect journalists (CPJ) / IFEX (International Freedom of Expression eXchange)
*505  $aCensored by the Judicial authorities
*505  $aThe provincial daily "Tous" was suspended for allegedly 
violating press law. The newspaper was reportedly charged with 
defamation, but no further details of the charge were given to the 
newspaper's editor-in-chief. The editor-in-chief was served a notice of 
the newspaper's suspension awaiting further legal action
*505  $aA Tehran court ordered the closure of the reformist daily Tous 
for allegedly violating Iran's press law. A Justice Department official 
said the paper had violated the law by using the same layout, content, 
and staff as a banned publication - the daily Jameah, which was Tous' 
predecessor. Despite the ruling, Tous resumed publication on August 2, 
under a different name, Aftab-e-Ruz. On the same day, a Tehran public 
court lifted the original ban, provided that the newspaper abide by 
regulations pertaining to layout
*505  $aJudicial authorities ordered the closure of the reformist daily 
Tous, effective September 16, for its "publication of articles against 
national security and general interests". Authorities sealed the Tous 
offices on the evening of September 15 and prevented distribution of 
the following day's edition. The paper's license was revoked on 
September 28
*506  $eCensored for political reasons
*518  $aOctober 19, 1995
*518  $aAugust 1, 1998
*518  $aSeptember 16, 1998
$3Newspaper
*651  $a7327
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aSuspended
*692  $aCensored
*74000$aAftab-e-ruz
$zTous

9914594
*041  $anor
*24500$aAftenposten
$bnyhetsorgan for joessinger
*260  $aOslo
$b[s.n.]
$c1941-42
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W. II Printing 
Collection. Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Norway 1940 - 1945
*505  $aCirculation: 500. - Stenciled
*505  $aNews service for members of the resistance movement. 
Approximately on April 17 1942, 5 members of the newsgroup were 
arrested, some of them initiators of the newspaper: Rolf Haugerud, Rolf 
Frantzen, Kaare Nielsen, Ester Norby and Henry Pedersen. Frantzen and 
Nielsen were sent to the German concentration camp Sachsenhausen. Mr. 
Fartein Valen-Senstad published "Fritt Folk" as a continuation of 
"Fram" and "Aftenposten" until he was arrested. The paper continued as 
"Fritt folk" and "Fram"
*506  $eCensored for political reasons
*518  $a1941-1945

*505  $aThis is the first time in the history of Pakistan that such a

law of 1960. The same order which was served on all six newspapers 
stated that the reason for the action was the "printing of sensational 
news which is an activity prejudicial to the maintenance of public order"

9907176
*041  $afre
*24500$aAurore plus
*260  $a[Cameroon
$bAurore]
*500  $aSource: Reporters sans frontieres (RSF) / International Freedom of Expression eXchange (IFEX)
*505  $aSuspended by the authorities
*505  $aThe independent newspaper "Aurore Plus" was suspended for six 
months. This action was in conjunction with the sentencing on 13 
January of its editor, Michel Michaut Moussala, to six months in prison 
and a fine of 10000 FF. The conviction followed a complained lodged by 
Jean Tchoussa Moussa Mbatkam, Director General of the National Ports 
Department of Cameroon (ONPC) and a deputy of the Rassemblement 
Democratique du Peuple Camerounais (RDPC), the governing party
*518  $aJanuary 13, 1998
$3Newspaper
*651  $a5118
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aSuspended
*70010$aMoussala, Michel Michaut
$eeditor

*503  $aIdentical indexes of forbidden literature were applied in all German occupied, as well as allied, countries: Denmark, Norway, France, Luxembourg, Belgium, The Netherlands, Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia, Belarus, Poland, Yugoslavia, Greece and Germany.

9914609
*041  $anor
*24500$aAvantgarden (Oslo)
*260  $aOslo
$b[s.n.]
$c1941-43
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W. II Printing 
Collection. Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Norway 1940 - 1945
*505  $aCirculation: 4000-18000. Printed
*505  $a"Avantgarden" was the first illegal paper to be printed in an 
illegal printing works. The first issue was published during the state 
of emergency in September 1941. The print was situated on the third 
floor in a public school in Oslo, although several hundred German 
soldiers lived in the school. Printing of the paper continued here 
until February 1942. In autumn of 1942 the main distributor, Rolf Lyng 
Nissen, was arrested, subjected to harsh interrogations and later 
deported to Sachsenhausen where he died. In summer of 1943 the editors 
split up, and the paper closed. Some group members started the paper 
"Svart paa hvitt". Publishing of "Avantgarden" was later resumed by the 
Norwegian Communist Party (NKP), now with the subtitle "hvori opptatt 
Aand og handling og: Organ for Aandsarbeider". Henrik Lunde, a most 
active member of the editorial staff, died during the shipwreck of the 
prison ship Westphalen
*506  $eCensored for political reasons
*518  $a1941-1945
$3Newspaper
*651  $a8040
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aIllegal
*70010$aNissen, Rolf Lyng
$edistributor
^

*362  $aVol. 1, no. 1 (1942)-vol. 1, no. 11 (1943)
*500  $aSource: The Royal Library, Denmark
*505  $aContents: News
*505  $aPublished by D.K.P.-group in Copenhagen
*503  $aCirculation: 350-500 printed, a total of 5.000 copies of 11 
issues
*506  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Denmark 1940-1945

9907158
*041  $aaze
*24500$aAvrazia
*260  $a[Azerbaijan
$bAvrazia]
*500  $aSource: Reporters sans frontieres (RSF) / International Freedom of Expression eXchange (IFEX)
*505  $aClosed down by the Minister of Information and the Media
*505  $aThe Minister of Information and Media wrote to the head of the 
Azerbaijan publishing company, Nazim Ibragimov, ordering him to stop 
printing the independent daily "Avrazia". At a meeting with the 
newspaper's publisher, Irfan Sapmaz, the minister complained about six 
stories published recently in "Avrazia". Since 3 August 1996, Avrazia 
has ceased publication for an indefinite period. According to the RSF, 
the minister's move infringes Article 14 of the law on the media, which 
states that the decision to close a publication can only be taken 
either by its founder or by a court, and in no circumstances on the 
orders of a ministry
*518  $aAugust 1, [August 3] 1996
$3Newspaper
*651  $a7216
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aClosed
^

9908769
*041  $anep
*24500$aAjko samacharpatra ; Jadanesh ; Janaahwan ; Yojana ; Jana ekta 
; Jana bhawana
*260  $aKathmandu, Nepal
$b[Ajko Samazharpatra ; Jadanesh [...]]
*500  $aSource: Reporters sans frontieres (RSF) / International Freedom of Expression eXchange (IFEX)
*505  $aSeized, confiscated by the Police
*505  $aSince 9 June 1998, several newspapers have been seized by 
police in Sindhulimadhi (320 km south-east of Kathmandu). The daily 
"Ajko Samacharpatra" and the weeklies "Jadanesh", "Janaahwan", 
"Yojana", "Jana Ekta" and "Jana Bhawana", all published in Kathmandu, 
were confiscated several times at the local market. Similar incidents 
were reported in other districts, such as Gorkha, Sindhuli, Rukum, 
Salyan, Tanahun, Dhading and Jajarkot, as the newspapers were about to 
be distributed. The newspapers had printed information about the 
misconduct of security forces, who are presumed to have killed civilians 
in clashes with Maoist guerrillas. Moreover, all articles that claim 
support for the Maoist movement because of government corruption have 
reportedly been banned
*506  $eSeized and confiscated for political reasons
*518  $a9 June 1998
$3Newspaper
*651  $a7439
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aSeized
*74000$aJadanesh
*74000$aJanaahwan
*74000$aYojana
*74000$aJana ekta
*74000$aJana bhawana
^

9908798
*041  $aara
*24500$aAkhir khaber
*260  $aSudan
$b[Akhir Khaber]
*500  $aSource: Reporters sans frontiers (RSF) / International Freedom of Expression eXchange (IFEX)
*505  $aShut down by the Press and Publications Council
*505  $aOn 19 January 1996, the independent daily newspaper "Akhir 
Khaber" was shut down permanently by the Press and Publications Council 
for having published articles deemed unethical ("contraires a 
l'ethique"). The paper was accused of having published sensational and 
exaggerated articles about crime, as well as articles that not only 
incited conflict between Shi'ite and Sunni Muslims but which also 
jeopardized state security. "Akhir Khaber" was suspended on 1 July 1995 
for having published an article that criticized the press law. The 
suspension was lifted on 18 July
*506  $eShut down for religious reasons
*518  $aJanuary 19, 1996
$3Newspaper
*651  $a5259
*691  $aReligious
*692  $aClosed

*500  $aSource: Palestinian media monitoring centre (a project of the

*505  $aClosed by the Palestinian National Authority (PNA)
*505  $aOrders for the closures of the pro-Hamas "Al Watan" and of "Al 
Istiklal" (see also Al Istiqlal), a paper linked to the Islamic jihad 
movement, were delivered by Palestinian police. Publishers Imad Falouji 
and Alaa Saftawi believe the measures are linked to articles which 
critized the PNA ant its head, Yasser Arafat, published in both 
newspapers. Both publishers were detained on 5 August for a few hours 
and released after extensive questioning

9908748
*041  $aara
*24500$aAl majd ; Al-mithaq ; Al-hadath ; Al-bilad ; Sawt al-maraa ; Al 
sayad ; Hawadeth al-sa'a ; Al-hadif ; Tareeq al mustaqbal ; Al-umma ; 
Al-urdun
*260  $aJordan
$b[Al Majd ; Al-Mithaq [...]]
*500  $aSource: Committee to protect journalists (CPJ) / International Freedom of Expression eXchange (IFEX)
*505  $aSuspended by the Ministry of Information
*505  $aThe Ministry of Information ordered at least twelve weekly 
newspapers to suspend publication because they had reportedly failed 
to meet requirements of the amendments to the Press and Publications 
Law that Jordan's king Hussein ratified into law on 17 May 1997. The 
Ministry of Information asserted that the twelve newspapers had failed 
to comply with Article 24 of the law, requiring that weekly newspapers 
raise their capital from 15000 JD (USD 20000) to 300000 JD (USD 
400000). The newspapers were granted three months to restructure their 
finances, after which time they face permanent closure if they have not 
complied to the law. CPJ protested the unreasonable and arbitrary 
requirements of Article 24, which appeared specifically tailored to 
force closure of weekly newspapers which are financially weaker and 
have been known for their independent and critical views of the 
Jordanian government
*506  $eSuspended for political reasons
*518  $aSeptember 24 and 25, 1997
$3Newspaper
*651  $a7331
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aSuspended

for the action

publication. The Ministry considered that the two editors should be 
permitted to exercise their functions as editors in chief because they 
are not members of the Association of Journalists and because they have 
not pledged their oaths before the Minister of Information

*041  $aara
*24500$aAl-mithaq
*260  $aJordan
$b[Al-Mithaq]
*500  $aSource: Reporters sans frontieres (RSF) / International Freedom of Expression eXchange (IFEX)
*505  $aSuspended by a Higher Court of Justice
*505  $aSuspended on the grounds that it had violated the controversial 
Press and Publications Law. The ruling against "Al-Mithaq" is the first 
concerning thirteen weeklies that the government suspended in September 
for allegedly violating the press law. The amendments to the Press and 
Publications Law oblige newspapers to have a minimum capital of 300000 
dinars available - instead of 15000 previously - if they wish to retain 
their publication licences. Most newspapers are unable to meet this 
requirement. Moreover, the amendments also provide for heavy sanctions 
against those newspapers guilty of crimes of "lese-majesty", "libel" 
and "undermining national unity and public morals"
*518  $aNovember 9, 1997
$3Newspaper
*651  $a7331

*692  $aSuspended

*100 1$aWalker, Alice,
$d1944-
*24510$aAlice Walker banned
$cwith an introduction by Patricia Holt.
*24630$aBanned
*260  $aSan Francisco
$bAunt Lute Books,
$c1996.
*300  $a105 p.
$c19 cm.
*500  $aSource: University of Hong Kong
*520  $aAs an introduction to Alice Walker, this small book presents 
two of Walker's most interesting stories, "Roselily" and "Am I Blue," 
and the beginning of her prize-winning novel, The Color Purple. Further, 
the pages of Patricia Holt's introduction and the appendices of letters 
to the editors and meeting transcripts exemplify ways in which these 
fictional works have been the center of volatile controversy. They have 
been the subject of removal from tests (as in the case of there cent 
literature-based assessment tests in California), from school libraries 
and from school curricula. These controversies, played out in 
communities across the United States, cut to the heart of issues of 
censorship and democratic process.
*65010$aWalker, Alice,
$d1944-

pro-Kurdish weekly "Newroz" have been subject to this new systematic 
confiscation effort

9924113
*041  $adan
*24500$aAlliance-revue
*260  $aCopenhagen
*300  $a2-3 pages
*310  $aPublished monthly Dec. 1943-March 1944
*362  $aVol. 1, no. 1 (1943)-vol. 1, no. 7 (1944)
*500  $aSource: The Royal Library, Denmark
*505  $aContents: News and articles
*505  $aThe paper was originally written and produced by one man. The 
paper vindicated the notion that Denmark after 29 Aug. was at war with 
Germany, and that the saboteurs were the country's soldiers. During a 
street raid all copies of one issue had to be left behind for the 
Germans to find. The paper ceased to publish, and its editor started 
working with other illegal work.
*503  $aCirculation: 50-150 printed, a total of 1000 copies of 7 issues
*506  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Denmark 1940-1945

^
9914598
*041  $anor
*24500$aAlt for Norge
*260  $aPorsgrunn
$b[s.n.]
$c1941-42
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W. II Printing 
Collection. Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Norway 1940 - 1945
*505  $aStenciled. - Distributed in the Skien-Porsgrunn area, as well 
as to contacts nationally
*505  $aPublication of the newspaper was upheld with great regularity 
in the Skien-Porsgrunn area, from the start of 1941. A driving force 
behind the paper was the parliament member Carl P. Wright. Several 
members of the group were arrested and sent to the Norwegian camp 
Grini. Most of them were subsequently deported either to Sachsenhausen 
or Natzweiler. The group had contacts within the Parliament, amongst 
them John Larsen. Larsen was persuaded by Wright to accept a position 
in the Reichskommissariat. Larsen obliged reluctantly, as he had to 
enlist in the NS. Larsen became most valuable to the newsgroup; 
obtaining pertinent information, also smuggling envelopes and stamps 
from the Reichskommissariat, enabling the group to distribute the paper 
nationally in the Reichskommissariats envelopes. When Larsen was 
discovered, he was subjected to severe torture during interrogations. 
He later died in Sachsenhausen. Carl P. Wright, arrested in 1941, was 
successfully freed by the group that published "London-nytt" and later 
transported to England. The total numbers of arrest is unknown, but at 
least 20 were sent to German concentration camps. Journalist Erling O. 
Pedersen died in police detention in Oslo due to torture. Borti 
Reichelt was later shot at Trandum
*506  $eCensored for political reasons
*518  $a1941-1945
$3Newspaper
*651  $a8040
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aIllegal
*70010$aWright, Carl P.
$eeditor
*70010$aLarsen, John
$einformant for the paper
*70000$aPedersen, Erling O.
$ejournalist
*70000$aReichelt, Borti
$eeditor
^
9914599
*041  $anor
*24500$aAlt for Norge
$borgan for nordmenn
*260  $aMo i Rana
$b[s.n.]
$c1943-44
*500  $aThe National Library of Norway, the W.W. II Printing 
Collection. Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Norway 1940 - 1945
*505  $aDistributed mainly locally, some copies were sent to Salten. - 
Stenciled, subtitle varies
*505  $aArticles and commentaries, local news and reports from the 
Norwegian news broadcastings at BBC
*505  $aThe paper was established by two leading members of the 
Norwegian Communist party. All equipment was hidden in a closed-down pig 
farm, and the paper kept these quarters until October 1944, when the 
news group had to go underground
*506  $eCensored for political reasons
*518  $a1943-1945
$3Newspaper

*505  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of

*505  $aPublished by the Norwegian Communist Party in Bergen

not far from Bergen. The paper was shut down due to arrests in autumn 1942

9914601
*041  $anor
*24500$aAlt for Norge
$cNKP
*260  $a[S.l.]
$bNKP
$c1944-45
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W. II Printing 
Collection. Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Norway 1940  1945
*505  $aPublished by the Norwegian Communist Party, place of 
publication not known. Distributed nation wide. Circulation of 22000 - 
48000
*505  $aWhen "Alt for Norge", published by the Norwegian Communist 
Party (NKP) in Bergen, shut down in the autumn of 1942, a new paper 
with the same name was published in January 1944. The number of copies 
each issue varied; one issue was published in 48000 copies. The paper 
continued publishing until the end of the war
*506  $eCensored for political reasons
*518  $a1944-1945
$3Newspaper
*651  $a8040
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aIllegal

$wNorske kommunistiske parti
*710 0$aNKP
$zDet Norske kommunistiske parti

9914758
*041  $anor
*24500$aJa, vi elsker
$bLondon-nytt pr ...
*260  $aDrammen
$b[s.n.]
$c1944-45
*300  $a2-4 p.
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing 
Collection. Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Norway, 1940 - 1945
*505  $aCirculation: 2500-3000. - Stencilled, 2-4 pages
*505  $aInitially published as "Alt for Norge" (noted as subtitle), but 
from June 1943 the paper continued as "London-nytts Buskerudsutgave". 
Herlov Rygh, one of members in charge, was arrested in November 1943, 
and the paper was renamed "Ja, vi elsker". Having established a 
substantial distribution net-work, the group kept publishing twice 
weekly until the liberation
*506  $eCensored for political reasons
*518  $a1944-1945
$3Newspaper
*651  $a8040

*24510$aFree expression and censorship in America
$ban encyclopaedia
$cHerbert N. Foerstel
*260  $aWestport, Conn.
$bGreenwood Press,
$c1997
*300  $aix, 260 p.
$c24 cm
*500  $aSource: National Library of Australia
*503  $aIncludes bibliographical references (p. [241]-242) and index
*520  $aAbortion, campaign financing, TV violence, homosexuality, and 
indecency on the Internet all have First Amendment implications, and all 
have been major political issues in the 1990s.During this decade, sex 
and secularism emerged as major targets of censorship, and an 
increasing number of Americans tested the limits of the Federal 
"decency" standards that were imposed on the arts, the broadcast media, 
and the Internet. America's interest in free expression has been 
paralleled by the growth of a powerful system of secrecy and censorship. 
This comprehensive encyclopaedia documents the full history of the 
struggle in Congress, in the courts, and in our communities to define the 
modern contours of the First Amendment

$220
*100 1$aBeisel, Nicola Kay
*24510$aImperiled innocents
$bAnthony Comstock and family reproduction in Victorian America
$cNicola Beisel
*260  $aPrinceton, N.J.
$bPrinceton University Press,
$c1997
*263  $a9701
*300  $ax, 275 p.
$c25 cm
*440 0$aPrinceton studies in American politics
*500  $aSource: National Library of Australia
*503  $aIncludes bibliographical references and index
*505 0$a1. Introduction: Family Reproduction, Children's Morals, and 
Censorship -- 2. The City, Sexuality, and the Suppression of Abortion 
and Contraception -- 3. Moral Reform and the Protection of Youth -- 4. 
Anthony Comstock versus Free Love: Religion, Marriage, and the Victorian 
Family -- 5. Immigrants, City Politics, and Censorship in New York and 
Boston -- 6.Censorious Quakers and the Failure of the Anti-Vice 
Movement in Philadelphia -- 7. Morals versus Art -- 8. Conclusion: Focus 
on the Family
*505  $aMoral reform movements claiming to protect children began to 
emerge in the United States over a century ago, most notably when 
Anthony Comstock and his supporters crusaded to restrict the circulation 
of contraceptive devices, information on the sexual rights of women, 
and "obscene" art and literature. Much of their rhetoric influences 
debates on issues surrounding children and sexuality today. In a book 
filled with Victorian accounts of pregnant girls, prostitutes, 
abortionists, Free Lovers, and others deemed "immoral," Nicola Beisel 
argues that rhetoric about the moral corruption of children speaks to an 
ongoing parental concern: that children will fail to replicate or exceed 
their parents' social position
*520 8$aIn a rare analysis of Anthony Comstock's crusade with the New 
York and New England Societies for the Suppression of Vice, Beisel 
examines how the reformer worked on the anxieties of the upper classes. 
Showing how a moral crusade can bring a society's diffuse anxieties to 
focus on specific sources, Beisel offers a fresh theoretical approach to 
moral reform movements
*65010$aComstock, Anthony,
$d1844-1915
*650 0$aChild rearing
$xMoral and ethical aspects
*650 0$aCensorship
$zUnited States
$xHistory
$y19th century
*650 0$aSocial mobility
$zUnited States
*650 0$aUnited States
$xMoral conditions
$xHistory
$y19th century
*650 0$aUnited States
$xSocial life and customs
$y1865-1918

*100 1$aGurstein, Rochelle.
*24514$aThe repeal of reticence
$ba history of America'a cultural and legal struggles over free speech, 
obscenity, sexual liberation, and modern art
$cRochelle Gurstein.
*250  $a1st ed.
*260  $aNew York
$bHill and Wang,
$c1996.
*300  $aix, 357 p.
$c24 cm.
*500  $aSource: University of Hong Kong
*503  $aIncludes bibliographical references (p. [309]-345) and index.
*520  $aThis striking study of America's battles over what we can 
decently say and do in public traces how and why principled debate about 
the character of our common world has been displaced by a new kind of 
public noise. Rochelle Gurstein offers a brilliant history of the 
arguments made for and against the forces - invasive journalism, realist 
fiction, and sex reform - that altered public discourse between the late 
nineteenth century, when they first appeared, and the 1960s, when 
new controversies erupted about mass culture, avant-garde art, and 
sexual liberation. Now the public sphere is dominated by rights talk, by 
puritan-baiting, and by knee-jerk liberalism or illiberalism. Is this 
the best we can do? Gurstein gives a detailed account of how the "party 
of exposure" successfully opened American public life to matters that 
had once been hidden away in private, and studies the unexpected 
consequences of that victory. And she retrieves a way of thinking, 
wrongly discredited as "Victorian," that could in fact move us beyond 
our stalemates over what should and what should not be said or done in 
public. Once, Americans influenced by the "party of reticence" held that 
if personal matters were exposed to public scrutiny they risked 
becoming trivial or obscene they thought that any indiscriminate display 
of private matters deformed standards of taste and judgement, lowered the 
tone of public conversation, and polluted public space. Ms.Gurstein's 
penetrating analysis suggests that we must reconsider these positions, 
and she establishes the vital connection between our legal-cultural 
history and current debates about obscenity, privacy, and issues of 
public decency.
*650 0$aFreedom of speech
$zUnited States.
*650 0$aObscenity (Law)
$zUnited States.
*650 0$aPrivacy, Right of
$zUnited States.

*041  $afre
*24503$aLa plume du jour
$wplume du jour
*260  $a[Cameroon
$bLa Plume]
*500  $aSource: Reporters sans frontieres (RSF) / International Freedom of Expression eXchange (IFEX)
*505  $aBanned by the authorities
*505  $aOn 11 September 1997, the day's edition of the privately-owned 
newspaper "La plume du jour" was seized; the next day, the paper was 
banned indefinitely. No official reason was given for the action. The 
11 September issue of "la plume du jour" contained two articles - one, 
titled "A moralizer without morals", which criticized the country's 
leadership, and the other, titled "Who are the prisons profiting?", 
which criticized the country's penal system
*506  $e[Probably] banned for political reasons
*518  $aSeptember 11, 1997
$3Newspaper

*24510$aTorture - a cancer in our society
$ba report prepared by H. Hunke and J. Ellis on torture in SWA/Namibia
*250  $a[Reprinted]
*260  $aLondon
$bCatholic Institute for International Relations
$c1978
*300  $a67 p.
$bill.
$c24 cm
*500  $aSource: University library of Namibia
*505  $aThis exposure of the systematic use of torture in Namibia was 
banned by the South African authorities prior to its publication. The 
purpose of the booklet is to support the protests against torture which 
have been made by the churches in Namibia on several occasions since 
1967, not least in the form of a pastoral letter signed by the most 
prominent church leaders in 1977. The major part of the booklet 
consists of a number of sworn statements which were filed in a case 
before the Windhoek Supreme Court (Eriksen/Moorsom 1989)
*505  $aCatholic Institute for International Relations in cooperation 
with British Council of Churches, 1978.

*041  $anor
*24500$aArbeiderbladet
*260  $a[S.l.
$bs.n.]
$c1942-44
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W. II Printing 
Collection. Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aOriginally the paper was named "Land og Folk", but eventually 
changed to "Arbeiderbladet" or "Total krig". At times the paper carried 
no name. The news group co-operated with the publishers of 
"Avantgarden". They were also members of the group behind "Svart paa
hvitt". Reidar Eker, Olav Torgersen and Gustav Sjaastad were arrested 
during the so called "Press crackdown" in 1944. In February 1944, the 
Nazi-authorities launched a major crackdown on illegal press 
activities, resulting in numerous arrests and closure of several 
newspapers

ladite note une mention qui n'est point sur la minute dudit arret,
$blaquelle note estinjurieuse ... l'honneur & ... la reputation de Me

*041  $aswa
*24500$aKasheshe ; Chombeza ; Arusha leo
*260  $aTanzania
$b[Kasheshe ; Chombeza ; Arusha Leo]
*500  $aSource: Media institute of Southern Africa (MISA) / International Freedom of Expression eXchange (IFEX)
*505  $aBanned by the Government of Tanzania
*505  $aKiswahili weekly tabloids. The government stopped the issue, 
publication and distribution of Kasheshe and Chombeza newspapers, in 
accordance with section 25(1) of the Newspaper Act, No. 3 of 1976. The 
Arusha Leo was banned under the Newspaper Regulation Acto of 1976, 
section 15(1)
*505  $aAccording to the Newspaper Act Section 25(1), "Where the 
Minister is of the opinion that it is in the public interest or in the 
interest of peace and good order so to do, he may, by order in the 
Gazette, direct that the newspaper named in the order shall cease 
publication as from the date (hereinafter referred to as 'effective 
date') specified in the order". According to the Newspaper Regulation 
Act of 1976, section 15(1), the minister responsible for information 
can cancel registration of any newspaper if he is convinced that such a 
paper was contravening the policy to which it had promised to adhere
*518  $aJune 6, 1998, with effect from June 8
$3Newspaper
*651  $a5264
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned

*74000$aArusha leo

*24500$aAs sharq
*260  $aQatar
$b[As Sharq]
*500  $aSource: Reporters sans frontieres (RSF) / International Freedom of Expression eXchange (IFEX)
*505  $aSuspended by the Ministry of Information and Culture
*505  $aThe daily "As Sharq" was suspended for three months by the 
Ministry of Information and Culture following the publication, in the 
newspaper's 17 June edition, of a poem by an Islamic fundamentalist 
from Saudi Arabia. The Ministry stated that the poem "undermined the 
heads of state and damaged relations with other friendly Arab countries"
*506  $eSuspended for religious and political reasons
*518  $aJune 26, 1996 - September 26, 1996

*041  $aira
*24500$aAsre-e-ma ; Sobh
*260  $aIran
$b[Asre-e-Ma ; Sobh]
*500  $aSource: Reporters sans frontieres (RSF) / International Freedom of Expression eXchange (IFEX)
*505  $aSuspended by the Judicial authorities
*505  $aOn 6 October Mohammad Slamanti, editor of the radical left-wing 
weekly Asre-e-Ma, was ordered to pay a fine equivalent to 1000 dollars 
and his newspaper was suspended for six months after it published 
"false and insulting articles". Mehdi Nassiri, editor of the 
conservative weekly Sobh, was fined the same amount and the newspaper 
was suspended for four months
*518  $aOctober 6, 1998
$3Newspaper

9908738
*041  $aira
*24500$aAsre-e-ma ; Sobh ; Jameh-salem
*260  $aIran
$b[Asre-e-Ma ; Sobh ; Jameh-Salem]
*500  $aSource: Reporters sans frontiers (RSF) / International Freedom of Expression eXchange (IFEX)
*505  $aSuspended by the Press Court in Tehran
*505  $aMohammad Salamati, director of the radical weekly "Asre-e-Ma", 
was sentenced, for having published "insulting and deceitful" articles, 
to a fine equivalent to USD 1000 and to a six-month suspension of the 
newspaper. Furthermore, Mehdi Nassiri, director of the hard-liner 
"Sobh", was sentenced to a fine equivalent USD 1000 and to a four-month 
suspension of publication. On 29 September, the publishing licences of 
the moderate monthly "Jameh-Salem" was revoked for defaming the later 
spiritual leader Ayatollah Khomeiny. The director of the paper, Siavoch 
Gouran, was given a one-year suspended jail sentence and a fine 
equivalent to USD 1000
*506  $eSuspended for religious and political reasons
*518  $aSeptember 29, 1998
$3Newspaper
*651  $a7327
*691  $aReligious
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aSuspended

*505  $aThe editorial staff, which consisted of three men, was shortly

9908811
*041  $atur
*24500$aAtilim
*260  $aTurkey
$b[Atilim]
*500  $aSource: Committee to protect journalists (CPJ) / International Freedom of Expression eXchange (IFEX)
*505  $aShut down by a Court
*505  $aOn 18 April 1996, a court ordered the leftist weekly "Atilim" 
closed for one month. A previous one-month closure order expired the 
same day. The latest order, issued under Article 8 of the Anti-Terror 
Law, is connected to two articles published by "Atilim" in 1995 
entitled "We won't let them divide Turkey up" and "Time for the final 
blow in the PKK (Kurdish Worker's Party) war."
*506  $eShut down for political reasons
*518  $aApril 18, 1996
$3Newspaper
*651  $a8048
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aClosed
*74002$aWe won't let them divide Turkey up
*74002$aTime for the final blow in the PKK war

*24500$aAtilim ; Ozgur genclik
*260  $aTurkey
$b[Atilim ; Ozgur Genclik]
*500  $aSource: Committee to protect journalists (CPJ) / International Freedom of Expression eXchange (IFEX)
*505  $aSuspended by Istanbul's State Security Court
*505  $aOn 19 March 1996, Istanbul's State Security Court ordered the 
closure for one month of the leftist daily "Atilim" for allegedly 
disseminating "separatist propaganda". The order also suspended "Ozgur 
Genclik", a magazine for youth, which is pulished by "Atilim"

9914612
*041  $anor
*2450 $aB.B.C.
$wBBC
*260  $aOslo
$b[s.n.]
$c1941-44
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing 
Collection. Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Norway 1940 - 1945
*505  $aCirculation: 25. Typed
*505  $a"B.B.C" later changed its name toe "Her er London". The paper 
was published approximately every night, and suffered no arrests. The 
paper was started at the time when the Norwegian public had their 
radios confiscated, and continued until April 1944, when the publishers 
engaged in other illegal activities
*506  $eCensored for political reasons
*518  $a1941-1945
$3Newspaper
*651  $a8040
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aIllegal
*74001$aHer er London
$zB.B.C.

9914613
*041  $anor
*2450 $aB.B.C. melder, dato
$wBBC melder, dato
*260  $aHarstad
$b[s.n.]
$c1943-45
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing 
Collection. Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Norway 1940 - 1945
*505  $aWhen the Norwegian public had their radios confiscated, Arne 
Torbergsen organised systematic listening to the forbidden B.B.C. He 
gathered trusted friends at his home and related the news from B.B.C. 
However, interest soon increased, and he began typing the news in 30 
copies which he distributed to trusted groups. Later the news were 
stencilled, and in the spring of 1945, the volume reached 250 copies
*505  $aCirculation: 150. Stencilled
*506  $eCensored for political reasons
*518  $a1943-1945

9908726
*041  $aeng
*10010$aSastrosatomo, Subadio
*24510$aNew era, new leader
$bBadio rejects the engineering by the new order regime
$cSubadio Sastrosatomo
*260  $a[S.l.
$bs.n.]
*300  $a22 p.
*500  $aSource: Institute for the studies on free flow of information 
(ISAI) / International Freedom of Expression eXchange (IFEX)
*505  $aBanned by the Indonesian government
*505  $aThe Indonesian government banned the book by an elderly 
politician, saying that the contents discredited the government, the 
military and President Suharto. Attorney-General Singgih signed a 
decree banning "New era, new leader : Badio rejects the engineering by 
the new order regime", a 22-page book by Subadio Sastrosatomo, 78, a 
prominent politican of the 1950s. The title refers to Suharto's "New 
Order" government which started in 1968 following a bloody coup attempt 
blamed on the communists. The content "can cause unrest, undermine 
public trust in the government, ABRI (the Indonesian armed forces) and 
the national leader," a national newspaper quoted Singgih as saying
*506  $eBanned for political reasons
*518  $aMarch 10, 1997
$3Book
*651  $a7526
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
^

$b[Bahar]
*500  $aSource: Committee to protect journalists (CPJ) / International Freedom of Expression eXchange (IFEX)
*505  $aCensored by the Ministry of Culture and Islamic Guidance
*505  $aThe weekly newspaper Bahar was suspended by an order of the 
Ministry of Culture and Islamic Guidance less than a month after it 
started its publication. The State Press Review Board, a special press 
screening committee, suspended the weekly until a "court hearing the 
case gives it verdict," for violating the country's press laws. No 
further reasons were given for this action
*518  $aMarch 12, 1996

*041  $aind
*110 0$aInstitute for studies on the free flow of information
*24510$aBayang bayang PKI
$cInstitute for studies on the free flow of information
*260  $a[S.l.]
$bThe Institute
*500  $aSource: Article 19 (A19) / International Freedom of Expression eXchange (IFEX)
*505  $aEnglish title: In the shadows of the PKI
*505  $aBanned by the Indonesian government
*505  $aThe book is about the violent political turbulence that occurred 
in Indonesia in 1965-66 which led to the assumption of power by current 
President General Suharto. The banning meant that it had been made 
a criminal offence in Indonesia for any person to possess, publish, 
distribute, trade or reprint "Bayang Bayang PKI"

$b[s.n.]
$c1941-42
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing 
Collection. Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Norway 1940 - 1945
*505  $aPublished once or twice weekly until April 1942. Circulation: 
1000-1500. Stencilled
*505  $aExtracts from radiobroadcasters from the London news, as well 
as material from other illegal papers
*505  $aA special edition, containing a secret report made by the 
Norwegian Nazi-authorities concerning the inhuman treatment that 4000 
teachers suffered during the transportation from Oslo to Kirkenes in 
1942. was printed in 3000 copies. Most copies were distributed through 
an organisation mainly consisting of young students. One of the 
distributors was betrayed by an informer and arrested 28 April 1942. 
Subsequently the organisation behind the paper was revealed

*505  $aSuspended by the State Press Committee
*505  $aTemporarily suspended from publication after repeated 
government warnings against "divulging state secrets" in violation of 
Art. 5 of the press law for a May 6 article investigating the special 
armed forces under the president's command. (The paper managed to 
re-register in July but faces closure if more than two warnings of 
press law violations are made within a year)
*505  $aOn 4 January 1996, a presidential decree gave the State Press 
Committee the power to oversee the re-registration of all 
privately-owned media, with the aim of guaranteeing "the right of the 
people" to be "honestly" informed of the activities of government 
authorities as well as of current events in Belarus

*24500$aBinders 1940
*260  $aBodoe
$b[s.n.]
$cAutumn 1940
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing 
Collection. Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Norway 1940 - 1945
*505  $aLists of people who joined the NS. Stencilled
*505  $aThe first illegal paper in Bodoe. Only one issue was published, 
as the publisher went to Oslo and continued his studies. The papers 
name - "Binders" (paper clip) - referred to the public action after the 
prohibition of political parties in 1940: patriots wore a paper clip on 
their coat lapels to deliberatly annoy the Germans and members of NS. 
Regarded as a provocation, wearing a paper clip would lead to arrests
*506  $eCensored for political reasons
*518  $a1940-1945
$3Newspaper
*651  $a8040
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aIllegal

9914618
*041  $anor
*2450 $aBlaatipsen
$wBlaatipsen
*260  $aOslo
$b[s.n.]
$c1944-45
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing 
Collection. Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Norway 1940 - 1945
*505  $aDistributed: Oslo. Circulation: 15. News extracts from radio 
broadcasters from London
*505  $aDuring the so-called "Press crackdown of 1944", distribution 
was abruptly stopped. A news group in Oslo started this paper, with 
news from London, as well as material from other illegal papers. 
Occasionally the paper was duplicated and disseminated by the 
recipients. As a rule, the paper was published daily
*506  $eCensored for political reasons

*24510$aBludas arba Lietuva buvusios Rusijos revoliucijos mete
$cDobilas
*260  $aTilsit
$b[s.n.]
$c1912
*300  $a428 p.
*500  $aSource: National Library of Lithuania: From the series of 
publications on Lithuanian libraries; historical sources and historical 
research : Forbidden Authors and Publications, The first years of the 
Soviet occupation 15.6.1940 - 21.6.1941, by Klemensas Sinkevicius. 
Published in Vilnius 1994. Original title: Uzdrausti autoriai ir 
leidiniai: pirmieji sovietinos okupaijos metai, 1940.06.15 - 
1941.06.21. - Vilnius, 1994.
*506  $aCensored or destroyed were all national or foreign publications 
considered to be harmful to the Communist party and to the teachings of 
Marx, Lenin and Stalin
$bCensoring body: Glavlit (The Supreme Board of Publishing and 
Literature, Council of Ministers of the Lithuanian SSR)
$eGrounds of censorship: political
*518  $a1940-1941
*520  $aThis translation of the title indicates the content of the 
book: Lithuania during the Russian revolution
*651  $a8060
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned

$b[printed by] Vort Arbeides Bogtrykkeri
$c1886, 1887
*300  $ap. 33-48, p. 81-96
$c18 cm
*500  $aSource: Thuesens "Beslaglagte og supprimerte boeker"
*505  $aCopy available at the Deichmanske library of Oslo, and issue 3 
available at the University library of Oslo
*505  $aTitle translated to english: Kristiania by day and night, or 
Off with the veil
*505  $aIssue 3 was immediately confiscated on orders of the Department 
of Justice, and the author charged and fined. The publication was 
continued, and in 1887 the 6th issue was confiscated and the author 
charged anew. The author was sentenced to jail on Penal code chapt. 8, 
3, and later also fined on Law of 27 Sept. 1799, 21. - The 
confiscated publications were destroyed
*505  $aThe two issues were also sold together with the publication 
"Samleie uden befrugtning"
*506  $eConfiscated on moral reasons

*041  $adan
*24500$aBoycott
*260  $aCopenhagen
*300  $a1-2 pages
*310  $aPublished monthly, twice a month Nov. 1941-Aug. 1944 and Jan. 1945
*362  $aVol. 1, no. 1 (1941)-vol. 1, no. 36 (1945)
*500  $aSource: The Royal Library, Denmark
*505  $aContents: News, particularly war-news together with informative articles
*505  $aNewspaper, edited and distributed by one man. Handwritten letters constituted the beginning of the paper. The publisher was arrested and the paper did not publish between 1 Aug. 1944- 1 Jan. 1945. One more issue was published after his release, after which the paper ceased publication and the publisher engaged in other illegal work
*503  $aCirculation: 40-1.600 printed, a total of 25.000 copies of 42 issues
*506  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Denmark 1940-1945

*505  $aThe publishing of the paper was indirectly caused by the German

tidsskrift. It was published only for a short period of time because 
the publisher was engaged in other illegal work

*100 1$aAldgate, Anthony
*24510$aCensorship and the permissive society
$bBritish cinema and theatre, 1955-1965
$cAnthony Aldgate
*260  $aOxford
$bClarendon Press ;
$aNew York
$bOxford UniversityPress,
$c1995
*300  $aviii, 171 p.
$bill.
$c23 cm
*500  $aSource: National Library of Australia
*503  $aIncludes bibliographical references (p. 157-168) and index
*505  $aA key decade in the postwar social and cultural history 
ofBritain, the period saw the country emerge from the 'doldrums era' of 
the fifties, to the permissive society of the 'swinging sixties'. A 
noticeable move towards 'decensorship' increasingly loosened the 
traditional constraints imposed on literature, stage, and films. Anthony 
Aldgate shows, however, that censorship altered the progression of the 
artistic and creative renaissance of this period, and how the process 
brought changes in the works of writers such as John Osborne, Shelagh 
Delaney, Alan Sillitoe, John Braine,Frederic Raphael, and Keith 
Waterhouse, and directors such as Tony Richardson, Lindsay Anderson,John 
Schlesinger, and Lewis Gilbert
*505  $aDrawing upon a mass of recently released or hitherto unseen 
documentation - including records, files, and photographs from the 
British Board of Film Censors and theLord Chamberlain's Office - Anthony 
Aldgate charts the impact of the censorship process between 1955 and 
1965 uponplay wrights and directors, many of whom endured the rigorous, 
sometimes rancorous, though often also fruitful,scrutiny of the film and 
theatre censors
*520  $aStage or film presentations of Look Back in Anger, A Taste of 
Honey, Saturday Night and Sunday Morning, Alfie, and Darling were much 
changed, even transformed, by censorship between1955-1965. Censorship 
and the Permissive Society explores the predicament writers and 
directors faced, and highlights the debate over the liberalizing or 
progressive aspects of the sea changes affecting British society at the 
time

*505  $aThe paper was published during the state of emergency on the 
22., 24. and 26. Sept. 1944. The Germans had given orders to shut off 
the gas, electricity and water supplies. After the state of emergency 
the paper ceased publication, as the reception and distribution of 
other illegal papers could resume. The publishers later published Frit 
Danmark and Nyhedstjenesten for Broenderslev og omegn
*503  $aCirculation: 200-400 printed, a total of 1.000 copies of 3 
issues
*506  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Denmark 1940-1945
*518  $a1940-1945
*518  $3newspaper

9908716
*041  $afre
*24503$aLe bucheron ; La griffe
$wbucheron ; La griffe
*260  $aGabon
$b[Le Bucheron ; La Griffe]
*500  $aSource: Reporters sans frontieres (RSF) / International Freedom of Expression eXchange (IFEX)
*505  $aBanned by the Minister of the Interior of Gabon
*505  $aThe minister ordered the head of the national printing press to 
cease printing the newspapers "Le Bucheron" and "La Griffe". The ban 
follows a series of articles and caricatures on the Smalto scandal (the 
Italian tailor who was on trial in France for allegedly setting up 
prostitution ring whose clients are said to include President Bongo.) 
The Minister of the Interior affirmed that "due to the severity of the 
situation, and the discredit which the newspapers have brought upon the 
public image of the country", he found himself obliged to put a 
protective ban on "the publication and circulation of the newspapers 
"Le Bucheron" and "La Griffe""
*506  $eBanned for political reasons
*518  $a20 April 1995
$3Newspaper
*651  $a5128
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aBanned
*74030$aLa griffe

*505  $aMainly domestic news. Typewritten/Stencilled
*505  $aThe paper was probably started in September 1941, and was 
characterised by the letters vvvv. The publisher is unknown. Presumably 
the paper was intended as a news bulletin to other papers. Published at 
least twice weekly. The Public Library of Bergen holds one copy.

Oslo

*041  $adan
*24500$aBudstikken
$b(Fredrikshavn)
*260  $aFredrikshavn
*300  $a4 pages
*310  $aPublished occasionally Nov. 1943-June 1944
*362  $aVol. 1, no. 1 (1943)-vol. 1, no. 9 (1944)
*500  $aSource: The Royal Library, Denmark
*505  $aContents: Informative articles with local news
*505  $aPublished by the D.K.P.-group in Fredrikshavn, which ran a 
distribution-centre for the paper Folkets kamp, Aalborg. Prior to
publishing Budstikken the group had published daily during the strike 
in 1943. The group-leader had to go underground in Aug. 1943, and in 
Feb./March 1944 five of the group members were arrested. In March 1945 
another member was arrested
*503  $aCirculation: 700 printed, a total of 7.000 copies of 9 issues. 
Not all issues were distributed

9923925
*041  $adan
*24500$aBudstikken
$bHaderslev, Aabenraa, Soenderborg
*260  $aAabenraa
*300  $a4-8 pages
*35000$aublished monthly June 1944-May 1945
*362  $aVol. 1, no. 1 (1944)-vol. 1, no 15 (1945)
*500  $aSource: The Royal Library, Denmark
*505  $aContents: Agitative and informative articles. Danish and 
foreign news together with local news
*505  $aPublished by the D.K.P.-group in the above mentioned cities. 
The paper did not publish in Nov. 1944 due to a Gestapo raid, where 
many group members were arrested. The collaborator Egon Noerregaard was 
arrested and murdered by the Germans 17 Dec. 1944. Henry V. Christensen 
was arrested in Oct. 1944 and deported to Neuengamme. He was later 
freed by Folke Bernadottes action, but died 21 May 1945 due to wounds 
from an attack. K.G. Kolding, Henry Jacobsen and L.P. Maansson were all 
executed the 19 April 1945
*503  $aCirculation: 1.500-6.000 printed, a total of 30.000 copies of 
15 issues. Not all issues were distributed

9923937
*041  $adan
*24500$aBudstikken
$bfrit Jysk tidende
*260  $aAalborg
*300  $a4-10 pages
*310  $aPublished monthly Jan.-Oct. 1944
*362  $aVol. 1, no. 1- vol.1, no. 6
*500  $aSource: The Royal Library, Denmark
*505  $aContents: Informative commenting articles
*505  $aThe paper was a continuance of the Anonymt blad : (Alborg). 
Swedish and Danish writers contributed with articles. From the main 
editorial office written copies were sent to Observer (Aarhus), 
Budstikken : Hjoerring, Horsens, Randers and Viborg, where affiliated 
news groups provided duplication and distribution. The editor-in-chief 
was arrested in Nov. 1944, and the paper ceased publication for two 
months. Nearly all of the members of the newsgroup, who also 
participated in many other illegal activities, were eventually arrested 
by the Gestapo, interned in the Danish camp Froeslev, deported to German 
concentration camps or escaped to Sweden. The paper was continued by 
the Fri Jysk tidende (Aalborg)
*503  $aCirculation: 2.000-2.500 printed, a total of 20.000 copies. Not 
all issues were distributed

*24500$aBudstikken for Kolding og omegn
*260  $aKolding
*300  $a46 pages
*310  $aPublished monthly June 1943-Jan 1944. 1944
*362  $aVol. 1, no. 1 (1943/1944)-vol. 1, no. 7 (1943/1944)
*500  $aSource: The Royal Library, Denmark
*505  $aCirculation: 300-3.000 printed, a total of 13.000 copies
*505  $aContents: Commenting agitative news with local news, together 
with disclosures of unpatriotic elements
*505  $aThe paper was a continuance of Folkets roest, Kolding. In Aug. 
1943 one of the group members was arrested by the Germans and tortured, 
and in Oct. another member was killed by the Germans in Lunderskov. 
Under the Gestapo raids in Kolding the 3. and 4. Dec. 1943 and 21. Jan. 
1944, more than 40 citizens of Kolding were arrested, among these 
several group members and the entire editorial staff, and the paper 
ceased publication. Several of the group members died, either during 
these raids or in German concentration camps: L.H.H. Alvin, Svend Otto 
Broedsgaard, Alfred Christensen, Karinus Johannes Feldsted, Joergen 
Kelstrup and Poul Seidenfaden
*506  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Denmark 1940-1945

members were arrested by the Germans

9914623
*041  $anor
*24500$aBulletinen
*260  $aKrageroe
$b[s.n.]
$c1941-45
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing 
Collection. Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Norway 1940 - 1945
*505  $aCirculation: 500. Stencilled. Distributed in Krageroe, as well 
as other places in Telemark, Norway
*505  $aThe first issue was published on August 9 1941, and represents 
one of the first stencilled radio-papers. More than 100 issues were 
published during the period, semi-regularly. The paper consisted mainly 
of two pages. The paper closed in March 1943 for security reasons, but 
the editor continued with other illegal work
*506  $eCensored for political reasons
*518  $a1941-1945
$3Newspaper
*651  $a8040
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aIllegal

9914624
*041  $anor
*24500$aBulletinen
*260  $aBergen
$b[s.n.]
$c1940
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing 
Collection. Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Norway 1940 - 1945
*505  $aStencilled
*505  $aPublishing started in autumn of 1940 and continued for two 
months before closure, due to the editor mr. Kvamme's engagement in the 
publishing of the Bergen-edition of "Fri fagbevegelse". Kvamme was 
arrested on January 5, 1942 and shot at Trandum on August 12, 1942
*506  $eCensored for political reasons
*518  $a1940-1945
$3Newspaper
*651  $a8040
*691  $aPolitical

9914625
*041  $anor
*24500$aBulletinen
*260  $aOslo
$b[R-gruppen]
$c1940-1945
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing 
Collection. Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Norway 1940 - 1945
*505  $aCirculation: 2000. Stencilled
*505  $aThe first issue was published in autumn of 1940 by the so 
called "R-group", a resistance movement. Several prominent politicians 
and press-people engaged in producing the paper, intended as a 
contactforum for the national resistance movement. Initially, 
"Bulletinen" was closely linked to "Fri fagbevegelse", but the two 
papers split up after the arrest of several members of "Fri 
fagbevegelse". Subsequently, numerous members of the "Bulletinen" group 
were arrested, many of which were sent to German concentration camps. 
Arne Krogh-Johanssen died in Mauthausen in 1945. Sigurd Evensmo and 18 
others were arrested during an attempt to sail to England. They were 
all executed, except for Evensmo, who also figured on the Gestapo death 
list. "Bulletinen" was taken over by Asbjoern Halvorsen and Gunnar 
Hansen, and when they were arrested, Jan Jansen took on the printing 
until he had to flee to Sweden. Ca. 150 issues were published, with an 
average of six pages
*506  $eCensored for political reasons
*518  $a1940-1945
$3Newspaper
*651  $a8040
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aIllegal

$eeditor

$eeditor

$eeditor
$wHalvorsen, Asbjorn
*70010$aHansen, Gunnar
$eeditor
*70010$aJansen, Jan
$eeditor

$epublisher
